FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. Born in New York City, Charlie was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Amherst College. He spent his early investment career at M.A. Shapiro, New Court Securities, and E.M. Warburg Pincus. For the past 32 years, Charlie and Kristin were business partners of Flood Gamble Associates, an investment management firm. Recently, Flood Gamble joined American Capital Management. Charlie was a dedicated and scrupulously honest businessperson who brought his deep intelligence to his tireless work for his clients. He enjoyed getting to know people of all backgrounds and loved nothing more than the everyday banter he had with friends, clients, neighbors, and everyone he encountered. He had a unique sense of humor and enjoyed gently ribbing people. His weekends were spent gardening and doing chores-Charlie's way of relaxing-in their second home and beloved community of Hudson, New York. Charlie loved the Hudson Valley and, with Kristin, was dedicated to the protection of the Hudson River and its environs. A lifelong Democrat and avid Obama supporter, Charlie enjoyed talking politics and railing against what he felt were the wrongs in society. He also contributed to many social causes. Charlie learned guitar as an adult and his playing and singing were an integral part of his time spent with family. A much-loved spouse, father, and grandfather, Charlie will be greatly missed by his wife of 40 years, Kristin Gamble, his daughters Deborah Flood and Karen Flood, his son-in-law Michael Benedek, and his grandchildren Naomi, Oscar and Violet. A celebration of Charlie will be held at 4:30pm on January 7 at the Metropolitan Club at 1 East 60th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Scenic Hudson at http://www.scenic hudson.org/donate, or Scenic Hudson, Attn: Veronica Renzo, One Civic Center Plaza, Suite 200, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. 1/3 FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. SHORT--Stephen. June 11, 1945-December 12, 2015. Stephen Short, a former Procter of the Admiralty, who also served in the Merchant Marine, passed away on December 12th. A longtime member of the New York State bar, his legal career encompassed maritime, criminal and personal injury law. In his youth, Mr. Short was also a gifted athlete, excelling as a swimmer, skier, sailor and avid tennis player. He was also deemed an Olympic caliber fencer by Maestro Odon Niederkirchner, of the NYAC. A colorful figure and lifelong champion of the underdog, he will be missed by all who loved him, including his sisters, Leslie Blake and Cheryl Bulbach and his brother, Dr. Wayne Blackmon. As per his wishes, Mr. Short's corneas were donated to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration. A Memorial will be held in mid-January at the Village Funeral Home. 1/3 SHORT--Stephen. GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3 GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Bay Shore, NY in 1937, she was the oldest child of Melissa Adams and Robert Hoffman Wiley. Melissa graduated from Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY in 1955. She attended Skidmore College and married in 1957. Howard and Melissa began their marriage at Dartmouth College. Howard's career brought them to many places: Munich, Germany; New Jersey; Minneapolis; San Francisco and finally settling down in Manhattan in 1987. Their lifelong home was on Lake George in Putnam, NY. Melissa brought music and friendship wherever she went; these passions defined her life. An extremely talented pianist, she played the organ for her church beginning at age 12. Melissa played an active role in her children's education, always volunteering, often as the accompanist for school musical productions. She sang in the Plymouth Church Choir and with the Plymouth Music Series. She supported the Minnesota Opera. Melissa was the Minister of Music, Organist and Choir Director at Suffern Presbyterian Church in Suffern, NY. While living in San Francisco, she sang in the Unitarian Church Choir and was a board member of The San Francisco Chamber Singers, now called Volti. In Manhattan, she joined the music department of the Rudolf Steiner School as a faculty member and retired in 2002. Melissa joined The Riverside Church in 1988 committed to making our world a better place through music. She was a member of The Riverside Choir, the Riverside Choral Society, served as Music Committee chair, raised funds for the Men's Shelter and was actively involved in the founding of the Catherine Van Buren Endowment Fund and the Friends of Music. She most recently enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, friends, and her dog. Melissa is survived by her children, Melissa Ann Geiger (Paul Marvin) of New York, NY, Kirsten Geiger Rider (Harold) of Winnetka, IL, Howard (Skip) Wilton Geiger III of New York, NY, Christopher Wiley Geiger of Larkspur, CA and her brother, William Adams Wiley (Lynn) of Grantham, NH; nine grandchildren, Paul and Oliver Marvin of New York, NY, Harold, Sarah and Christopher Rider of Winnetka, IL, Lillian Geiger of New York, NY, Wiley, Bourke and Finley Geiger of Larkspur, CA as well as many adored nieces, nephews and her beloved dog Libee. Her husband of 56 years, Howard Wilton and her brother, George Martin Wiley III, predeceased Melissa. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Music, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, 10027. Services will be held at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY at 12:00pm on Monday, January 4. A memorial reception will immediately follow. There will be additional opportunities to meet with family and friends. 1/3 GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3 DICKLER--Ruth. KELLY--Ellsworth. Pratt Institute is saddened by the loss of one of the most defining abstract painters of our time, Ellsworth Kelly, who studied at the institution in the 1940s. Minimal in form, bold in color, and widely influential, Kelly's work is featured in prominent museums, galleries, and private collections across the globe. As a true pioneer extending the boundaries of creativity, Kelly will be revered for his iconic style and artistic vision for generations to come. Pratt Institute Board of Trustees Chairman Bruce Gitlin, President Thomas F. Schutte 1/3 KELLY--Ellsworth. FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of SUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single-handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war, he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He was survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Feilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3 FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. Born in New York City, Charlie was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Amherst College. He spent his early investment career at M.A. Shapiro, New Court Securities, and E.M. Warburg Pincus. For the past 32 years, Charlie and Kristin were business partners of Flood Gamble Associates, an investment management firm. Recently, Flood Gamble joined American Capital Management. Charlie was a dedicated and scrupulously honest businessperson who brought his deep intelligence to his tireless work for his clients. He enjoyed getting to know people of all backgrounds and loved nothing more than the everyday banter he had with friends, clients, neighbors, and everyone he encountered. He had a unique sense of humor and enjoyed gently ribbing people. His weekends were spent gardening and doing chores-Charlie's way of relaxing-in their second home and beloved community of Hudson, New York. Charlie loved the Hudson Valley and, with Kristin, was dedicated to the protection of the Hudson River and its environs. A lifelong Democrat and avid Obama supporter, Charlie enjoyed talking politics and railing against what he felt were the wrongs in society. He also contributed to many social causes. Charlie learned guitar as an adult and his playing and singing were an integral part of his time spent with family. A much-loved spouse, father, and grandfather, Charlie will be greatly missed by his wife of 40 years, Kristin Gamble, his daughters Deborah Flood and Karen Flood, his son-in-law Michael Benedek, and his grandchildren Naomi, Oscar and Violet. A celebration of Charlie will be held at 4:30pm on January 7 at the Metropolitan Club at 1 East 60th Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Scenic Hudson at http://www.scenic hudson.org/donate, or Scenic Hudson, Attn: Veronica Renzo, One Civic Center Plaza, Suite 200, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. 1/3 FLOOD--Charles Andrew, 77, died at his home in New York City on December 23 with his adored wife Kristin by his side. HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. She was 77. Judi was an amazing mother, grandmother, sister, and woman. She enjoyed gardening, reading, painting, sculpting, music and building and fixing things. For a small person, Judi had a huge heart and always opened up her home and her heart to help others. After Hurricane Sandy, she had many displaced people stay with her for extended periods of time and never felt like it was too much; instead, she always said that she wished they would stay longer since she really enjoyed being with them and helping them. Judi was born to Abraham and Rose Shereff on June 18, 1938 in New York City and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her parents. Judi is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Susan Shereff; daughter Helaine Harte and son-in-law David Rhode, her sons and daughters-in-law Douglas and Ronni Harte and Jonathan and Belynda Harte; and the pride of her life, her grandchildren, Alex and Haleigh Harte and Tyler, Casey and Rebecca Rhode. Judi loved all animals. After being a teacher and raising her children, she worked at Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, NJ, and spent many years rescuing and rehabilitating injured and orphaned wild animals and birds. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Turtle Back Zoo in Judi's honor. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in New York City at 11:30am on Sunday, January 3rd. 1/3 HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. SABATINE--Carol Roth. Died peacefully of a rare neurodegenerative brain disease on November 12th, at the age of 80. A native of Port Huron, Michigan (born July 3, 1935), she graduated from the University of Michigan Architecture and Design School (1957). Soon after, she moved to New York City to begin a career in interior design. In 1960, she married Leo E. Sabatine (died 1976). She dedicated her life to raising her two sons and to volunteer work. She was a fixture in Brooklyn Heights, the neighborhood where she lived for over 40 years. She will be remembered for her kindness, elegance and utmost generosity. Along with serving on the vestry at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, she served numerous executive positions, including president, for the Brooklyn Woman's Exchange and Brooklyn Heights Garden Club. She had a great interest in the arts and culture, loved travelling with her sons, enjoyed playing and watching tennis, and spending time at her beloved beach club. Her brain was donated for research to the Mass General Hospital Frontotemporal Disorders Unit. She is survived by her loving sons, Michael and Edward, by her daughter-in-law Marcela, and granddaughter, Maria Carolina, brother, John R. Roth (Karen), sisters Miriam L. Roth and Judith R. Armstrong (Ned). A memorial service will be held at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, at 11am on January 9th. 1/3 SABATINE--Carol Roth. She received her master's degree from Columbia University and became a nurse practitioner, specializing in women's health for over 40 years, most recently at New York University. She retired in December 2014. Erica is survived by her loving husband of 32 years, Thomas James Zielinski of Old Bridge; son, Adam Zielinski of Asbury Park; daughter, Brenna Zielinski of Manhattan; and sister, Beth Herzig of Miami. GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3 GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Phyllis. He is survived by his two daughters, Lise and Wendy, sister Shirlee (Geri Grossman), and his grandson Miles Emanuel. He retired as an accomplished electrical engineer at Fairchild Camera. He had a major impact on the East End community. Irving was a tutor of ESL students at East Hampton High School, a friend to senior citizens through R.S.V.P. and an active Democrat. He was devoted to his tennis and golf games. Irving was a loyal and generous friend to many. Contributions may be made in his memory: Cinema Arts Centre, Huntington, Long Island or the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3 HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. GORDON--Marjorie. Passed away on December 8, 2015. A kind and generous person with a great sense of humor, she was devoted to her many friends and students. She taught at many universities and music camps, and was the founder of the Detroit Opera Theater, the Detroit Piccolo Opera, and co-founded "Adventures in Music" for the Detroit Public School system. She made her operatic debut with the New York Philharmonic, and went on to sing with the best orchestras in the country. She gave recitals with her violist husband, Nathan Gordon in Greece, Europe, Canada, and Israel. She was a member of many musical organizations, including the Florida Music Teachers Association, the National Teachers Association, and the Broward County Music Club. She left one child, Peter Gordon and three grandchildren, Ted and Josh Gordon and Douglas Schwartz. 1/3 GORDON--Marjorie. Passed away on December 8, 2015. ROSENFELD--Henry. Henry passed away peacefully in his home on December 26, 2015. He is survived by his children Jessica, Diego (Heidi), Julia, grandchildren and brother Albert. Henry was an elegant man with a strong moral compass, a passion for world affairs and Israel. He was born in Chile and travelled throughout South America with his family for business in film, settling in Argentina. After graduating Columbia University and falling in love with America he raised a family with his late wife Leonor in Scarsdale, NY. Henry was prosperous in business which afforded him time to spend with family, contribute to Jewish causes, and play golf with friends. His generosity and cheerful sense of humor will be missed. Rest in peace father, friend, husband, and visionary. 1/3 ROSENFELD--Henry. Henry passed away peacefully in his home on December 26, 2015. PEREZ--Alfredo J.,83, of Sheffield, MA died peacefully on December 18. Born in New York City, he graduated from Columbia College and Columbia University Graduate School of Business. After serving in the U.S. Navy he had an extensive career in public service, most notably as deputy CEO of Planned Parenthood; acting director of the U.S. Peace Corps; president of the college, The Experiment in International Living and its School for International Training; confidential assistant, U.S. Agency for International Development; and Senior Vice President, Management of Family Health International, supervising programs with USAID for controlling the AIDS epidemic in developing countries. Charming and courtly, Alfredo was a gentle, loving man, compassionate, caring and always there for you. An avid reader, he had a love of good conversation, strong coffee, and music - classical, jazz, flamenco, and blue grass. His greatest love was for his family - his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He is survived by his wife, Ann-Marie Light, daughters, Carole Montanari and Xanne Perez; sons, Tom, Robbie and Michael Perez; twelve grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren; brother, George Peters; and his first wife, Florence Perez. A memorial will be held in the spring. Contributions may be made to The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, theaftd.org. 1/3 PEREZ--Alfredo J.,83, of Sheffield, MA died peacefully on December 18. CALLAHAN--Daniel J. III, 83, died peacefully on December 30, 2015 at the home he shared with his wife of 59 years, Colleen Mount Callahan. Mr. Callahan was a fourth generation Washingtonian. He was an Insignis Medal recipient at Georgetown Preparatory School (1950), a member of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity at Williams College (B.A.) (1954), served four years in the ROTC, and served in the United States Air Force, retiring as a Captain (1954-1956). He held positions with many financial institutions over his long career in banking, including Chairman of American Security Bank, President of Riggs National Bank and an executive of Chase Manhattan Bank. Mr. Callahan's most recent position was as Treasurer and Vice Chairman of The Morris and Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation of Washington, DC. He had many business interests and held various board positions including Chairman of the Greater Washington Research Center, Vice Chairman of the Atlantic Council, Director Emeritus of Easter Seals Greater Washington- Baltimore Region, Inc., Independent Director of Washington Mutual Investors Fund Inc. and Director of Washington Gas Light Company and WGL Holdings Inc. Mr. Callahan's spiritual faith was an important and sustaining force throughout his life. He supported numerous charitable organizations. In 1991, he was bestowed the honor of Knight Commanders of the Order of St. Gregory the Great by Pope John Paul II; Cardinal James Hickey announced the papal honors. He is predeceased by his son, Daniel J. Callahan IV, his sister, Gerry Callahan Corcoran, and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Callahan Jr. He is survived by his wife, Colleen Mount Callahan; his children, Carey S. Callahan, Caren A. Callahan, Carolyn Callahan Keller, Colleen Callahan Brown; nine grandchildren; three great-grandsons; and his sisters, Joanne McClure and Mary Alicia Callahan. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, 1725 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC., 20036 at 1pm on Monday, January 4, 2016. Immediately following the Mass, friends will be received at the Mayflower Hotel, 1127 Connecticut Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20036. The interment will be private for family only. Memorial contributions may be made to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Washington. 1/3 CALLAHAN--Daniel J. KELLY--Ellsworth. The Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies (FAPE) is profoundly saddened by the loss of Ellsworth Kelly. Revered and respected throughout the world, we will be forever grateful for his generosity, for the works he gave so enthusiastically to our Foundation, and for his commitment to FAPE's mission. From a sketch on a paper napkin came the design of two magnificent wall sculptures for the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, which greet more than 2,000 Chinese visa applicants daily, employing the colors in our two countries' flags to honor the relationship between the U.S. and China. In Berlin, Ellsworth watched as the 40- foot-high 'Berlin Totem' he created for the U.S. Embassy soared through the air to be placed in its courtyard garden. His extraordinary lithograph, 'Leaves,' adorns the walls of 50 U.S. embassies; and he contributed to our Collection at the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, as well as our millennium Gift To The Nation. He also donated the actual award that we present annually to the recipient of the Leonore and Walter Annenberg Award for Diplomacy through the Arts; the first honoree was Justice Stephen Breyer, who collaborated with Ellsworth on his site- specific installation at the John Joseph Moakley Courthouse in Boston. Ellsworth's last gift to FAPE was the establishment of an endowment, entitled the Ellsworth Kelly Fund for Preservation, to ensure FAPE's Collection is maintained in perpetuity at no cost to the government. Words cannot express how important Ellsworth was to FAPE. His gifts are a testament to his creativity, his genius and his extraordinary spirit. He will always remain in our memory, and his work will remind us of his belief in the importance of art as a means of freedom of expression and cross-cultural understanding. We send our deepest condolences to Jack Shear. Jo Carole Lauder, Chairman Eden Rafshoon, President Darren Walker, Vice President Elizabeth Pozen, Secretary Harrison Wellford, Treasurer Ann Gund, President Emerita Wendy Luers, President Emerita Jennifer Duncan, Director Robert Storr, Chairman, FAPE Professional Fine Arts Committee and Dean, Yale School of Art 1/3 KELLY--Ellsworth. MANICAS--Peter T. 1934-2015. Peter T. Manicas, retired professor of philosophy at Queens College, City University of New York and the University of Hawaii at Manoa, passed away on December 27 in Honolulu. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Kenoe Kauanoe 'Ti' Manicas, and their son Teddy (Theodore). Their daughter Tautasi died previously. Born into a Greek and Sicilian immigrant family in Binghamton, NY, Manicas was raised in Batavia, NY. He saw active service in the U.S. Air Force in the late 1950s and attained the rank of Captain. He received his BA from Syracuse University, and his MA from the University of Buffalo and his PhD in philosophy from SUNY Buffalo (1963). Professor Manicas moved to Hawaii in 1988 where he served as Professor of Sociology and Director of the Interdisciplinary Studies program at the University of Hawaii at Manoa (1988-2011). Early in his career he taught at C.W. Post College and Ohio Wesleyan University. A testimony to his scholarly productivity, Manicas published thirteen books and over fifty papers on realist philosophy, American pragmatism, and social theory including: "The Death of the State" (1974); "A History and Philosophy of the Social Sciences" (1987); and "A Realist Philosophy of Science" (2006). The consistent recipient of teaching awards, Manicas touched the lives of thousands of students. Peter was endowed with a fiery passion for social justice and had a curious mind, a wicked humor, and an open heart. A consummate epicure, he also was an enthusiastic fan of the New York Yankees, Knicks, and Giants, in addition to being a powerful presence in pick-up basketball. Peter was in many ways larger than life and will be irreplaceable. Services will be held at Borthwick Mortuary in Honolulu. 1/3 MANICAS--Peter T. 1934-2015. Peter T. KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Julliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Gilbert Kaplan, passionate music lover and devoted and beloved husband of Lena. Gil joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1980, and served the Hall with devotion for more than thirty-five years. Gil brought his financial acumen and keen insight to Carnegie Hall's management as a longstanding member of the Finance and Operations Committee, where he helped govern major institutional advances from the restoration of Carnegie Hall to the creation of an education center. Following his successful career in business and journalism, Gil became a celebrated scholar of Gustav Mahler, establishing the Kaplan Foundation and conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with leading orchestras around the world. Gil was invited by the Vienna Philharmonic to conduct the original version of Mahler's Second Symphony and his recordings of the Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic were very successful. Gil demonstrated his deep love and knowledge of music every season as a frequent concertgoer, and many members of the Carnegie Hall's family were honored to be guests on Gil's acclaimed radio program "Mad About Music." We will always remember Gil for his warmth, musical scholarship, and his love of Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lena; his devoted children Kristina, Claude, John, and Emily; and their families and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert. HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. She was 77. Judi was an amazing mother, grandmother, sister, and woman. She enjoyed gardening, reading, painting, sculpting, music and building and fixing things. For a small person, Judi had a huge heart and always opened up her home and her heart to help others. After Hurricane Sandy, she had many displaced people stay with her for extended periods of time and never felt like it was too much; instead, she always said that she wished they would stay longer since she really enjoyed being with them and helping them. Judi was born to Abraham and Rose Shereff on June 18, 1938 in New York City and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She was preceded in death by her parents. Judi is survived by her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Susan Shereff; daughter Helaine Harte and son-in-law David Rhode, her sons and daughters-in-law Douglas and Ronni Harte and Jonathan and Belynda Harte; and the pride of her life, her grandchildren, Alex and Haleigh Harte and Tyler, Casey and Rebecca Rhode. Judi loved all animals. After being a teacher and raising her children, she worked at Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, NJ, and spent many years rescuing and rehabilitating injured and orphaned wild animals and birds. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Turtle Back Zoo in Judi's honor. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in New York City at 11:30am on Sunday, January 3rd. 1/3 HARTE--Judith Shereff, of Livingston, NJ, passed away in New York City on Wednesday, December 30, 2015 after a long and courageous fight with lung cancer. DICKLER--Ruth Crohn, 102, died Thursday, December 31, at home of natural causes. A native New Yorker who loved the City-its parks, museums, concert halls and people, she lived with her father, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn, after her parents divorced when she was 12. Her brother, the late Dr. Eduard B. Crohn, lived with their mother, Lucile Pels Crohn, in Europe. Mrs. Dickler met her husband-to-be, the late Gerald Dickler, when they were in their mid-teens. He was already attending Columbia College; she went to Barnard College for two years before dropping out to help support them while he began practicing law. She was librarian and book review editor, as well as a board member, at Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York. She also served as president of The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Hospital. But her greatest passion was philanthropy. She and her husband made large donations to institutions they both loved: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Public Library, the 92nd Street Y, UJA and Planned Parenthood. They also planned gifts to other city institutions. She leaves three daughters, Abby Pratt of West Stockbridge, Massachusetts and Squirrel Island, Maine, and her husband, Larry Pratt; Jane Dickler Lebow of New York City and Susan Dickler of New York City and West Tisbury, Massachusetts, and her husband, Sig Van Raan. She had four grandchildren, Sam Pratt, Kate Lebow, Dr. Robert Pratt and Emily Hoppe; three stepgrandchildren, Jackson, Sofie and Zoe Van Raan, and four great-grandchildren, Lucy and Owen Pratt and Naomi and Jacob Lawrence. There will be no funeral. A gathering of family and friends is planned in the future. Donations in her memory may be made to The Burrill B. Crohn Research Foundation at Mount Sinai Medical Center or Citizens Housing and Planning Council. 1/3 DICKLER--Ruth Crohn, 102, died Thursday, December 31, at home of natural causes. GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. Born in Bay Shore, NY in 1937, she was the oldest child of Melissa Adams and Robert Hoffman Wiley. Melissa graduated from Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY in 1955. She attended Skidmore College and married in 1957. Howard and Melissa began their marriage at Dartmouth College. Howard's career brought them to many places: Munich, Germany; New Jersey; Minneapolis; San Francisco and finally settling down in Manhattan in 1987. Their lifelong home was on Lake George in Putnam, NY. Melissa brought music and friendship wherever she went; these passions defined her life. An extremely talented pianist, she played the organ for her church beginning at age 12. Melissa played an active role in her children's education, always volunteering, often as the accompanist for school musical productions. She sang in the Plymouth Church Choir and with the Plymouth Music Series. She supported the Minnesota Opera. Melissa was the Minister of Music, Organist and Choir Director at Suffern Presbyterian Church in Suffern, NY. While living in San Francisco, she sang in the Unitarian Church Choir and was a board member of The San Francisco Chamber Singers, now called Volti. In Manhattan, she joined the music department of the Rudolf Steiner School as a faculty member and retired in 2002. Melissa joined The Riverside Church in 1988 committed to making our world a better place through music. She was a member of The Riverside Choir, the Riverside Choral Society, served as Music Committee chair, raised funds for the Men's Shelter and was actively involved in the founding of the Catherine Van Buren Endowment Fund and the Friends of Music. She most recently enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, friends, and her dog. Melissa is survived by her children, Melissa Ann Geiger (Paul Marvin) of New York, NY, Kirsten Geiger Rider (Harold) of Winnetka, IL, Howard (Skip) Wilton Geiger III of New York, NY, Christopher Wiley Geiger of Larkspur, CA and her brother, William Adams Wiley (Lynn) of Grantham, NH; nine grandchildren, Paul and Oliver Marvin of New York, NY, Harold, Sarah and Christopher Rider of Winnetka, IL, Lillian Geiger of New York, NY, Wiley, Bourke and Finley Geiger of Larkspur, CA as well as many adored nieces, nephews and her beloved dog Libee. Her husband of 56 years, Howard Wilton and her brother, George Martin Wiley III, predeceased Melissa. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends of Music, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, 10027. Services will be held at The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY at 12:00pm on Monday, January 4. A memorial reception will immediately follow. There will be additional opportunities to meet with family and friends. 1/3 GEIGER--Melissa Brown Wiley, died of natural causes in New York City on Saturday, December 19, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. DICKLER--Ruth Crohn. The Division of Gastroenterology at The Mount Sinai Medical Center is saddened at the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Ruth Crohn Dickler, daughter of a founding giant of our profession, Dr. Burrill B. Crohn. The miracle of Ruth's life is not simply that she remained active and healthy for 102 years, but that she used those years to raise such a distinguished and devoted family, to support such a wide range of worthy causes, and to promulgate the timeless legacy of her father at Mount Sinai by underwriting many of the ground-breaking research and educational initiatives of our Division. Bruce E. Sands, MD, The Dr. Burrill B. Crohn Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Steven H. Itzkowitz, MD, Professor of Medicine and Oncological Sciences, Program Director David B. Sachar, MD, Clinical Professor of Medicine; Division Chief Emeritus 1/3 DICKLER--Ruth Crohn. COOPERSMITH--Dr. Sy, psychoanalyst, died peacefully at home of respiratory arrest on November 6, 2015. He was 84. Sy was born on June 19, 1931 and grew up in Boston. He graduated from Boston Latin High School, Bates College and earned his doctorate at Columbia University Teachers College. Sy did his psychoanalytic training at the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis where he also served on the faculty and was a senior clinical supervisor. He is survived by his wife Dr. Valerie Pinhas, and daughter Andie Coopersmith. A Memorial Service will be held at NPAP on January 10, 2016 from 1-3pm, 40 West 13th St., NY, NY 10011. 1/3 COOPERSMITH--Dr. Sy, psychoanalyst, died peacefully at home of respiratory arrest on November 6, 2015. KELLY--Ellsworth. The Checkerboard Film Foundation is very saddened at the passing of Ellsworth Kelly, seminal artist and true gentleman. In 2007, we were privileged to produce, with Jo Carole Lauder, the documentary film, "Ellsworth Kelly: Fragments." Most memorably, we filmed Ellsworth in Paris as he recounted his formative experiences while living there from 1948 to 1954, and his exploration of French culture and monuments that so informed his work. He said: "In my paintings, I am not inventing; my ideas come from constantly investigating how things look." They included the shadows of an arch of a bridge on the Seine ("White Plaque: Bridge Arch and Reflection," 1951-55); the external chimneys on the wall of a building ("Ormesson," 1950); and the long angular windows at The Museum of Modern Art, Paris ("Window," his first panel painting, 1949). We send our very sincere condolences to Jack Shear, whose inspiration and guidance were invaluable. The Board of Trustees and Edgar B. Howard, President 1/3 KELLY--Ellsworth. HSU--Ta Chun. Weill Cornell Medicine is saddened by the passing of our friend Ta Chun Hsu, former president of The Starr Foundation and a graceful, longtime generous champion of our institution. His legacy endures through the C.V. Starr Biomedical Information Center, which the foundation established in 1987 to provide physicians, scientists, staff and students with the latest information resources. The foundation's commitment to education is also exemplified in the C.V. Starr Scholarship, which has supported the training of generations of medical students since its creation nearly 30 years ago. We will greatly miss his friendship and sage advice. Our condolences to The Starr Foundation leadership, his family and his many friends. Dr. Laurie H. FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of CUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single- handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He is survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Freilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3 FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. BAKER--Elizabeth, "Betsy." Elizabeth "Betsy" Lentz Baker died unexpectedly in Savannah, GA on December 4, 2015 after a brief illness. A resident of Manhattan's Upper West Side for 50 years, and more recently of Tuxedo Park, NY, Betsy was born in Kittanning, PA, on August 13, 1936 to Elizabeth Fleming Wagner and William Roy Baker and was raised in State College, PA and Wilmington, DE where she graduated from Alexis I. DuPont High School. She earned a B.S. degree from Drexel University specializing in textile chemistry and was a member of Delta Zeta Sorority. She worked for Celanese, Hercules, Inc., and as a commercial print model. Betsy volunteered with The Leukemia Society, Community Board 7, various cancer support groups, and Manhattan's Bull Moose Dog Run. A longtime survivor of tonsilar area cancer, which she faced with courage and conviction, Betsy was an inspiration to all those who knew her. Despite the physical challenges with which the disease left her, Betsy was able to flourish thanks to the devoted care of her physician, Dr. Margaret Lewin. Survived by stepfather Romeo Barrick Wagner, cousins Robert Hayman, Sr. (Sally), Robert Hayman, Jr. (Sherry), and Victoria Sutton (James) and her poodle, Queen Victoria "Tori." Donations in Betsy's memory may be made to "Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine/The Albert L. Lewin, M.D. Award Fund for Clinical Excellence in Pediatrics," Office of Advancement Services, Case Western Reserve University, 10900 Euclid Avenue, Cleveland, Ohio 44106-7035. Telephone 216-368-2000. 1/3 BAKER--Elizabeth, "Betsy." Elizabeth "Betsy" Lentz Baker died unexpectedly in Savannah, GA on December 4, 2015 after a brief illness. SHORT--Stephen. June 11, 1945-December 12, 2015. Stephen Short, a former Procter of the Admiralty, who also served in the Merchant Marine, passed away on December 12th. A longtime member of the New York State bar, his legal career encompassed maritime, criminal and personal injury law. In his youth, Mr. Short was also a gifted athlete, excelling as a swimmer, skier, sailor and avid tennis player. He was also deemed an Olympic caliber fencer by Maestro Odon Niederkirchner, of the NYAC. A colorful figure and lifelong champion of the underdog, he will be missed by all who loved him, including his sisters, Leslie Blake and Cheryl Bulbach and his brother, Dr. Wayne Blackmon. As per his wishes, Mr. Short's corneas were donated to the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration. A Memorial will be held in mid-January at the Village Funeral Home. 1/3 SHORT--Stephen. ERIKSEN--Stein, December 11, 1927-December 27, 2015. Stein Eriksen Lodge mourns the passing of our namesake Stein Eriksen. It was Stein's vision that created the lodge. He set the high standard for hospitality and service that still exists today. His celebrity charisma created a special ambiance within the Lodge, restaurant and out on the mountain that was warm and inviting and contributed to Deer Valley Resort being named number one and the Lodge being named "World's Best Ski Hotel." As one of the most recognized names in the ski world, Stein Eriksen has been synonymous with skiing style and elegance for more than 60 years. Our thoughts are with his wife Francois and his son Bjorn, three daughters, Julianna, Ava and Anja, as well as his five grandchildren. Stein will be sorely missed. Ski well our friend! Dennis A Suskind, President Russ Olsen, CEO 1/3 ERIKSEN--Stein, December 11, 1927-December 27, 2015. Stein Eriksen Lodge mourns the passing of our namesake Stein Eriksen. DICKLER--Ruth. It is with deep sadness that we note the passing of Mrs. Ruth Dickler who first joined The Citizens Housing & Planning Council as a volunteer in 1962, where she began to build and shape our archival library. She was an important resource for New York City's researchers, academics, and students. Upon her retirement she became a member of CHPC's Board of Directors. A talented writer and editor, her research and organizational skills helped to shape CHPC's work for nearly five decades. A mentor and friend to all of us at CHPC, her legacy continues in the historic library that bares her name. Our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends and to our city which has lost a great lady. 1/3 DICKLER--Ruth. MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3 MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. PERALTA-RAMOS--Arturo Jr. Born in Southampton, L.I. to Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos Sr. and Millicent Rogers, Arturo Henry Peralta-Ramos, Jr. passed away December 21, 2015, at his home in Taos, NM at the age of 87. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, Jacqueline Blanchard Peralta-Ramos, his son Arturo H. Peralta-Ramos III, (Eunjae Peralta-Ramos) of Jackson Hole, Wyoming, his daughter Lorian Peralta- Ramos Buckley, (Peter Buckley) of Aiken, South Carolina, his grandchildren, Sascha and Syler Peralta-Ramos, Jamie and Ian Buckley, Ashley and Lindsey Gamble, and his step-mother Mercedes Peralta-Ramos. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his older half brother Peter Salm, and younger brother, Paul Peralta-Ramos. Arturo Peralta-Ramos Jr. grew up in the United States and Europe. He attended school on both continents, most notable being Institut Le Rosey in Switzerland and Staunton Military Academy in Virginia. He briefly attended the University of Virginia before striking off to pursue his life-long career as an Entrepreneur. Based out of New York City, his business interests spanned a diverse array of industries including mining, flour milling, defense, electronic marketing, recreation and entertainment. His most recognized achievement was as a co-founder of Comp-U- Card International, one of the leading edge precursors to online marketing. A staunch patriot, over many years Arturo acted as an advisor to the Lyndon Johnson administration, along with numerous senators and congressmen, and participated in a number of classified assignments. One of his greatest passions throughout his life was bird hunting. In that pursuit he travelled the world and won numerous domestic and international championships. Arturo also maintained strong affection for the Millicent Rogers Museum in Taos, NM, dedicated to the life and artistic creations, collections and endeavors of his mother, Millicent Rogers. Over the years he served on the board and participated both as an avid advisor and benefactor. Funeral services will be performed on January 9, 2016, at 11am at the San Francisco de Asis Church in Ranchos de Taos by Father Dino Candelaria, followed by a final graveside blessing at the Taos Sierra Vista Cemetery. A reception for family and friends will be held at the Trading Post Restaurant following the interment. In lieu of flowers, gifts or donations in his memory should go to the Millicent Roger Museum. www.millicentrogers.org 1/3 PERALTA-RAMOS--Arturo Jr. Born in Southampton, L.I. to Arturo H. HSU--Ta Chun (T.C.), our esteemed president emeritus and director, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, December 27, 2015 at the age of 97. T.C. lived a full life. He was a gentleman in every sense of the word, dedicated, deeply loyal, a good friend, and counselor to generations of colleagues at the Starr Companies and The Starr Foundation. T.C. was born in Beijing in 1918, son of Yu Hsuen Yang (mother) and Tsing Lo (Singloh) Hsu (father), brother of the late Ta Ching (Irene) Hsu and the late Vivian Hsu Jee, and beloved "Uncle T.C." to many. T.C.'s father was one of the earliest backers of Cornelius Vander Starr's businesses in Shanghai and, when Tsing Lo Hsu was killed in the early days of World War II, Mr. Starr brought T.C. to America to complete his college education. T.C. never forgot Mr. Starr's generosity and friendship and made significant contributions to Starr's organizations over the years. T.C. attended the University of Shanghai from 1936-1938 and graduated from Haverford College in 1942 with a B.S. in economics. He earned a masters degree at Columbia University in the School of Journalism in 1944 and began his career with the news department of the Chinese Information Service in New York. He returned to Shanghai to work on the Chinese edition of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, newspapers owned by Mr. Starr. In 1947, T.C. joined the staff of the Shanghai Commercial & Savings Bank until 1949, and then joined Starr's American International companies in Hong Kong and later San Francisco. In 1964, T.C. moved to New York to work directly with Mr. Starr on a variety of projects, including the management of The Starr Foundation, Mr. Starr's private philanthropic foundation. After Mr. Starr's death in late 1968, T.C. became President of The Starr Foundation and served in that role until 1999. T.C. remained an active director of the Foundation until his death. T.C. will be laid to rest in China. A memorial service in New York City is planned for a future date. M.R. Greenberg, Chairman The Starr Foundation 1/3 HSU--Ta Chun (T.C.), our esteemed president emeritus and director, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, December 27, 2015 at the age of 97. HARRISON--Maria T. (nee Preite) of Short Hills died on Thursday, December 31st, surrounded by her family. She was 56. Maria was born in Brooklyn, NY, and has lived in Short Hills for the past 25 years. She graduated from St. John's with a B.A., which led her to pursue a masters in education at Caldwell College. Maria was a firm believer in the potential of others and dedicated her life to helping them achieve it. Former New York City Mayor Ed Koch appointed her to serve on the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, where she advocated for gender equality through dialogue and policy proposals. She later spent a decade as an elementary school teacher for Ecole Toussaint Louverture, a public elementary school in East Orange, New Jersey. Maria was the beloved wife of Edmond Harrison, devoted mother of Meghan and E.J. Harrison, loving daughter of Joseph Preite and the late Gloria Mercorella Preite, and dear sister of Ralph Preite. KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Gilbert Kaplan, passionate music lover and devoted and beloved husband of Lena. Gil joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1980, and served the Hall with devotion for more than thirty-five years. Gil brought his financial acumen and keen insight to Carnegie Hall's management as a longstanding member of the Finance and Operations Committee, where he helped govern major institutional advances from the restoration of Carnegie Hall to the creation of an education center. Following his successful career in business and journalism, Gil became a celebrated scholar of Gustav Mahler, establishing the Kaplan Foundation and conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with leading orchestras around the world. Gil was invited by the Vienna Philharmonic to conduct the original version of Mahler's Second Symphony and his recordings of the Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic were very successful. Gil demonstrated his deep love and knowledge of music every season as a frequent concertgoer, and many members of the Carnegie Hall's family were honored to be guests on Gil's acclaimed radio program "Mad About Music." We will always remember Gil for his warmth, musical scholarship, and his love of Carnegie Hall. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lena; his devoted children Kristina, Claude, John, and Emily; and their families and loved ones. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert. HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Phyllis. He is survived by his two daughters, Lise and Wendy, sister Shirlee (Geri Grossman), and his grandson Miles Emanuel. He retired as an accomplished electrical engineer at Fairchild Camera. He had a major impact on the East End community. Irving was a tutor of ESL students at East Hampton High School, a friend to senior citizens through R.S.V.P. and an active Democrat. He was devoted to his tennis and golf games. Irving was a loyal and generous friend to many. Contributions may be made in his memory: Cinema Arts Centre, Huntington, Long Island or the Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3 HIRSCHBERG--Irving, resident of Amagansett, NY, died suddenly on December 30th at age 88. KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. Generous, gracious and beautiful, she lost her beloved husband, Irving, in 1996, just short of their 59th Wedding Anniversary. She is survived by her children, Anne Davis and Peter (both widowed), grandchildren Ariel Morvan, David and Zoe, and three great-grandchildren, Eleanor, Angelica and Benjamin. Adele studied dramatic arts at NYU, acted briefly, and was passionate about music, art and travel. She loved her home in New York and a second home in Cannes, France, in which places she brought family and friends together. While her children were growing up in Scarsdale, NY, she was an officer of the PTA, served as co-leader of a Girl Scout troop and hosted a foreign exchange student, Delcia Bence Rusk, to whom she remained close all her life. In a brief reprise of her acting career, she played Mrs. Frank in a 1961 Scarsdale High School production of The Diary of Anne Frank in which her daughter, Anne, was played by Liza Minnelli in her acting debut. A lover of music and constant concertgoer, she was an active Board Member of Young Audiences, the Bowden International Music Festival, and the Marlboro Music Festival, which she attended for over forty years. She took great pleasure in encouraging young musicians at the beginning of their careers. The funeral is private. There will be a memorial service, the date to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Marlboro Music, 1528 Walnut Street, Suite 301, Philadelphia, PA 19102. 1/3 MOSKOVITZ--Adele. Died December 31, 2015, two days after her 100th birthday. TRYFOROS--Nicholas James, July 27, 1923-December 31, 2015. Nicholas James Tryforos, son of James and Garufa, was the youngest and last survivor of thirteen children. In explaining why "Mama and Papa had thirteen children, not twelve or fourteen" Nick said, "When I was born, papa picked me up, checked me out, and said 'Mama! FINALLY a perfect baby.'" A lifelong New Yorker, he was a proud graduate of The Greek American Institute, Theodore Roosevelt High School and New York University. He served in the Army in WWII. After basic training, the Army sent him to language school to become a Hindustani interpreter. He received horse cavalry and military intelligence training, and then served in the Philippines and in General MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo during the occupation of Japan. Nick used his Hindustani skills for the rest of his life to surprise and delight both friends and complete strangers from India. After returning from Japan Nick worked for 15 years in the family flower and novelty business, then had a 25-year career with the IRS, retiring in 1986 as a Group Manager, supervising large corporation tax audits. Amateur gymnast, superb photographer, family documenter and archivist, Nick was the favorite uncle of many and worked hard to make and cultivate relationships with family and friends. He collected any piece of junk that could potentially serve a future purpose, taught his children the value of a dollar and the importance of grunt labor, and was the original tiger mom and DIY guy. He was the resident teaser (while being wheeled to major surgery with four children at home, Nick whispered to his wife "don't worry dear, as long as we have our health!") and an inveterate joke teller ("Have you heard the one about the skeleton that walked into a bar..."). Nick delighted in meeting his children's friends, showing them photos related (and unrelated!) to their discussion, and always enjoyed giving them another tour of the garage! Nick was quietly proud of everyone in his family, and his family was very fortunate to have him. He leaves behind his dear wife of 63 years and best friend Mary, and his children, Margaret and her husband Paul, Jim and his wife Sue, Tom, and Tina and her husband David. He also leaves his grandchildren, Peter, Evan, Kate and her husband Pat, John, Lucas, Eva, and Eli, and great-grandson Theo. Within minutes of Nick's passing, his second great-grandson, Grant, was born. Visitation will be held from 6 to 9pm Monday, January 4th at Frederick Funeral Home in Flushing, and funeral services at 11:30am Tuesday at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to SmileTrain.com, DoctorsWithoutBorders.com or World Vision In Support of Syrian Refugees. 1/3 TRYFOROS--Nicholas James, July 27, 1923-December 31, 2015. BOESCHENSTEIN--Josephine Moll, "Molly." October 29, 1930-December 30, 2015. Josephine Moll "Molly" Boeschenstein passed away peacefully Wednesday, December 30, 2015, in Hobe Sound, FL. Molly was born Josephine Hamlin Moll on October 29, 1930, in Detroit, MI, to Josephine Hamlin and The Honorable Lester Moll, a prominent Detroit prosecutor and judge. She grew up in Grosse Pointe, MI. In 1953, she married William W. Boeschenstein, who was working for Owens Corning in Detroit. The couple later moved to Perrysburg, Ohio, where they raised four sons. Mr. Boeschenstein ultimately became Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Owens Corning in Toledo, Ohio. Although her husband became the public face of the company, Molly was a genuine partner to him throughout his career. Molly was known for her intelligence, style, love of competition, and her outstanding, irreverent sense of humor. Conversations with her were punctuated by astute observations, humorous ripostes, and often times belly shaking laughter. She had a wide and deep circle of friends from every corner of her life. Molly was deeply involved in a number of civic and charitable organizations. Notably, she was the first President of the St. Vincent Medical Center Foundation in Toledo, OH, a committed volunteer at the Toledo Museum of Art, and a member of the Board of Directors of The National Council on Alcoholism and Addiction and The Freedom Institute in New York. Molly and her husband have made their principal residence in Hobe Sound, FL. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, William W. Boeschenstein, sons William Jr., Michael, Peter and Stephen, their spouses, and 10 grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Funeral services are pending. Memorial contributions may be made to the Toledo Museum of Art, the Jupiter Medical Center Foundation in Jupiter, FL or the Martin Health Foundation in Stuart, FL. 1/3 BOESCHENSTEIN--Josephine Moll, "Molly." ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3 ROGERS--Wayne M. COTTY--Edmond, 92, died December 28 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. Son of Gustave Cotty and Marie Parisod, he earned his MBA from the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. There he met his wife, Yvette Mina Chuard. He emigrated to New York City in 1948 to join the investment firm of Istel, Lepercq & Co. He went on to be president of John Bristol & Co. (1964) and founder of Cotty, Feldman & Co. (1971) which merged with New Court Securities/Rothschild, Inc. (1974) where he directed their Investment Management Division until his retirement (1993). He was very active in the Scarsdale Congregational Church. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 57 years, Yvette, and by his treasured daughter, Isabelle Cotty. He is survived by his daughter Anne-Claude Cotty and son Phil Cotty. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, January 9 at 11am at the Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his honor to White Plains Hospital or Scarsdale Volunteer Ambulance. 1/3 COTTY--Edmond, 92, died December 28 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3 GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3 HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. ROGERS--Wayne M. The staff at Kleinfeld Bridal is deeply saddened by the death of its Chairman, Wayne Rogers. From the 1990's to the present, Wayne in partnership with Ronald Rothstein and Mara Urshel, built Kleinfeld into the most successful designer bridal retailer in the world. He helped expand the Kleinfeld name into 150 countries through the hit "Say Yes to the Dress" TV show and he licensed the brand to HBC for Canada. Wayne followed no rules, no industry practices and believed one always had to enjoy the freedom of free thought with no boundaries. Wayne loved Kleinfeld and its success, its dedicated staff and its brides. His personal charm and caring nature was a blessing to everyone who worked at Kleinfeld. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to Amy, Laura, Bill and their families. He will be truly missed. Ronald R. Rothstein and Mara Urshel 1/3 ROGERS--Wayne M. KELLOGG--James C.,IV. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, on July 2, 1939. Departed on December 31, 2015 and resided in Short Hills, NJ. Memorial Service Friday, January 8th, 12:00pm, Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Luncheon Friday, January 8th, after the service, Short Hills Club, 144 Highland Avenue. James C. Kellogg, philanthropist and loving husband, father of three children, and grandfather of nine grandchildren, died on Thursday of congestive heart failure, surrounded by his family. He was 76 years old. Jim was a graduate of The Pingry School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. During his career, he was a partner at the Manhattan law firm Townley & Updike, the President of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, the President of the J.C. Kellogg Foundation, and a valued trustee of many non-profit boards. He was most proud of his philanthropic work in Elizabeth, New Jersey. He cherished the idea of creating opportunities for people from disadvantaged backgrounds to be healthy, learn, and grow. Jim grew up in Elizabeth, NJ and spent his summers in Bay Head, NJ, where he made many friends whom he kept throughout his life. Those friends would gather on a regular basis for couples' dinners and bridge marathons. He looked forward to Romeo lunches, Scorpions bridge, and the Literatti book club, where he always touted the latest political book. In the past few years, Jim became a Life Master at bridge by participating in ACBL bridge tournaments across the country. He spent his winters at Yeamans Hall in South Carolina. Jim had a deep commitment to public service; he advised and served on the boards of Frost Valley YMCA, Bay Head Chapel, Short Hills Community Congregational Church, Point Pleasant Hospital, the Children's Specialized Hospital, Trinitas Regional Medical Center, Meridian Health Systems, Council of Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, Union County College, Bloomfield College, the Prudential Insurance Company, New Jersey State in the Trust for Public Lands, and the Scholarship Fund for Inner City Children. He was appointed by the Governor to the boards of New Jersey Transit and the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. His lifelong passion for philanthropy paled in comparison to his love for his family- his wife, three children, and nine grandchildren. Jim was happiest at family gatherings and loved playing backgammon and gin rummy with his children and grandchildren. Pop Pop's signature backgammon move was to wait for his opponent to admit defeat only to turn the board around and play the losing side, teaching his mentee how to stage a comeback and win! He was active in every aspect of his children's and grandchildren's lives, including attending their school events, and offering advice on and help with work issues. He is survived by his wife, Gail Chambers Kellogg, his children, Jimmy Kellogg, Kate Kellogg, and Elizabeth Kellogg Winterbottom; adoring grandchildren, Emily, Jimmy and Grace Kellogg; Chris and Andrew Kellogg Peeler; Hailey, Francesca, Maile, and Penelope Winterbottom; and his three younger brothers, Peter, Kelly, and Rusty. A service to celebrate his life will be held Friday, January 8th at 12:00pm at the Short Hills Community Congregational Church. Immediately following the service, the family invites all attendees to join them for lunch at the Short Hills Club. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Frost Valley YMCA in Claryville, NY. For more info, or to send condolences to the family, please visit www.bradleyfuneral homes.com. 1/3 KELLOGG--James C.,IV. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, on July 2, 1939. KAPLAN--Gilbert. The Juilliard School community mourns the passing of Gilbert Kaplan, a member of the school's Evening Division faculty since 2000 and devoted supporter of the arts around the world. Through his popular courses on Mahler for music lovers, Gil brought his extraordinary expertise and passion to a composer whose work is better understood through his scholarship and performances. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lena, and his beautiful family. He will be deeply missed by all. Joseph W. Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Danielle La Senna, Director of Juilliard's Evening Division 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert. GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. He was five days short of his 93rd birthday. Eddie lived a unique and exceptional life. As a young man, Eddie fought bravely in World War II and received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star. He had many achievements. He was a competitive springboard diver and in 1942 made the U.S. Open at Forest Hills; he had a world-renowned stamp collection and gave generously to many causes in Santa Fe. In 1992, Eddie co-founded BGK Group, a highly successful commercial real estate company headquartered in Santa Fe. Under Eddie's leadership the company acquired a large national portfolio as well as premier buildings in New Mexico, Texas and elsewhere. By 2010, when New York-based Rosemont Real Estate acquired part ownership of BGK, Gilbert's company was the largest holder of commercial real estate in New Mexico, owning properties in 28 states. He was "larger than life" say his children. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Peaches, seven children, Robin, Alexandra (Ronald), Dominique, Nina, Sasha, Beatrice and Zoe and three grandchildren, Brooke, Ross and Yeabsira. 1/3 GILBERT--Edward M.,dubbed the "Boy Wonder of Wall Street" in the 1950's, died peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on Wednesday, December 23, 2015. MOSLER--Sheila Hawley Sanders. The loving family of Sheila Hawley Sanders Mosler, 80, is profoundly saddened by her passing on January 4, 2016. Sheila was an incredibly loving and giving person and will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Born and raised in New York City, Sheila was formerly married to John Mosler Sr., Chairman of Mosler Safe Company, mother to her sons John and Bruce, and daughter Michele. Her father was Chairman of the Hudson River Day Line and an original partner of the Circle Line. Sheila's career, which spanned more than 30 years, was focused on bridging her skills and expertise in acting between political, corporate, humanitarian and educational areas in New York City and internationally. She served as the Deputy Commissioner and Executive Lobbyist for the New York State Department of Commerce, where she was appointed by Governor Nelson Rockefeller as a corporate liaison with the top management of Fortune 500, medium sized and small businesses to maintain and bring new business to New York State. She also served as a Special Assistant and Lobbyist for the Governor's Consultant on Labor & Commissioner of Human Rights, where she acted as a bridge to the labor unions and minority grounds in New York State, as well as a Member of the Governor's Special Committee, where she was appointed as the youngest member of a special committee to review state laws and procedures in the areas of human rights and labor relations. While Sheila excelled in her professional career, she also had a place in her heart for giving back to the community. She was also a successful cabaret singer and recorded an album, "Rare! Hot!". Sheila was a graduate of Finch College and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from St. John's University. Sheila is survived by her sons, Bruce (Wendy) Mosler and John (Jean) Mosler, her daughter Michele Mosler, and her grandchildren David and Charlotte Mosler. The wake honoring her life will take place on Thursday, January 7th from 5 to 8pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel and a private Mass will follow on Friday, January 8th at 9:30am at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. 1/3 MOSLER--Sheila Hawley Sanders. MORRISON--Richard. We mourn the loss of our partner, colleague and friend Richard Morrison, who suffered a heart attack and passed away on January 4. He was an important member of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for nearly 30 years, and was deeply devoted to his work, colleagues and clients. As Managing Partner of Weil's Miami office and a longstanding partner in our Real Estate practice, Richard was instrumental in the development of Weil's presence in Miami and was also integral in helping to shape our global Real Estate practice. Richard split his time between our Miami and New York offices, and was known and loved by partners, associates and staff across all of Weil's offices. He graduated with a B.A. from Vanderbilt University in 1981 and earned a J.D. from the University of Florida's Levin College of Law in 1984. We will remember Richard with the utmost respect and admiration, and we offer our deepest sympathy to his family; he will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues at Weil. 1/3 MORRISON--Richard.
