KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. ROSS--Donald K. Sr.,of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Water Mill, NY and Vero Beach, FL passed away at his home in New Jersey on January 5, 2016 after an extended illness. He was born in 1925, the son of Alexander and Althea Grainger Ross of Ridgewood, NJ. Mr. Ross was the valedictorian of his Ridgewood High School class in 1942 and matriculated as an undergraduate at Yale University in the V 12 United States Navy training program. While at Yale he was a member of the varsity swim team and majored in electrical engineering. Upon graduation he was commissioned as an ensign in the U.S. Navy. After three years of active duty in the Navy he resigned his commission and entered Harvard Business School. Upon graduation he spent a summer as a counselor at Camp Pemigewassett in Wentworth, NH where he and his brother Sandy had spent their boyhood summers. He soon joined New York Life Insurance Company as a trainee. Mr. Ross spent his entire professional career at New York Life, culminating with his serving for a decade as its CEO, President and Chairman of its board of directors. Don met the love of his life, Mary Fyffe, in the second grade. They were married in 1949 and she survives him; along with their four children Catherine Lesher (Charles), Susan Morris (William), D. Keith Ross, Jr. (Suzanne) and Deborah Cipriano (Gaetano), along with nine grandchildren, three step-grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his younger brother Alexander "Sandy" Ross and many nieces and nephews and their families. He was a beloved family man and a true gentleman of the old school with a calm demeanor, impeccable judgment, and an illuminating smile. Mr. Ross was a life- long, enthusiastic golfer. He was an active member of the Arcola Country Club in Paramus, NJ, National Golf Links of America in Southampton, NY, and the Moorings Country Club, Vero Beach, FL. He also was a longtime member of the Indian Trail Club in Franklin Lakes, NJ where he played competitive platform tennis for many years. In addition to his career with New York Life Insurance Co., Mr. Ross was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the YMCA of Greater New York; Trustee of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. and the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation; and a member of the Boards of Directors of the Committee for Economic Development and the New York Chamber of Commerce. In addition he was an elder and building committee member of the Presbyterian Church of Franklin Lakes, NJ and he was instrumental in the construction of its Church on Franklin Lake Road. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, January 8, 2016 at 4pm at the High Mountain Presbyterian Church, 730 Franklin Lake Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Hackensack UMC Foundation Heart Failure Fund, 360 Essex Street, Suite 301. Hackensack, NJ 07601 or by calling 551-996-3720. Services by Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417. For further info. please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call us at (201)891-4770. 1/3 ROSS--Donald K. BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3 BOULEZ--Pierre. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. An uncommon man in every respect, he founded Institutional Investor magazine at the age of 26, serving as its Publisher and Editor-in-Chief for the next two decades, only to embark on a second life as a renowned amateur conductor of Mahler's Second Symphony. He said of the symphony that it "wrapped itself around me and never let go." This passion ultimately led to conducting engagements with over 60 orchestras throughout the world, acclaimed recordings of the work with the London Symphony Orchestra and the Vienna Philharmonic and, more recently, a faculty position at Juilliard. His private life was just as rich. He married the woman he loved at first sight, loved her deeply to the end, and together they presided over a family of four beautiful children, Kristina Wallison, Claude Davies, John Kaplan and Emily Kaplan, and eight grandchildren. All grieve profoundly at his passing, but feel deeply blessed to have loved and been loved by this remarkable man. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) in New York City, on Thursday, January 7 at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Friends are invited to email stories and condolences to: gilkaplanfamily@gmail.com. 1/3 KAPLAN--Gilbert, died peacefully on the morning of January 1, 2016, with Lena, his wife of 45 years, and their four loving children by his side. BOULEZ--Pierre. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the passing of Pierre Boulez, our bold and innovative Music Director from 1971 to 1977 as well as a trailblazing composer and thinker. Under Boulez, the Philharmonic introduced concert formats that brought the audience in direct contact with composers and performers, including the informal Rug Concerts and downtown Prospective Encounters. He returned in 1986 for a 14- event series highlighting his work as conductor, composer, and leader of the Ensemble Intercontemporain. In 1992 he celebrated the Philharmonic's 150th anniversary in a concert also led by former Music Directors Zubin Mehta and Kurt Masur. In the same year Boulez was made an Honorary Member of the Society, an honor shared by such figures as Wagner, Stravinsky, and Bernstein. New York Philharmonic Music Director Alan Gilbert said: "Pierre Boulez was a towering and influential musical figure whose Philharmonic leadership implicitly laid down a challenge of innovation and invention that continues to inspire us to this day. To me, personally, he also was an unfailingly gracious mentor and friend, from the years when I worked with him in Cleveland and when I was appointed to the Philharmonic to the last time I saw him in Baden- Baden on a Philharmonic tour. I will miss his musicianship, kindness, and wisdom." The New York Philharmonic family sends our love and compassion to his family. 1/3 BOULEZ--Pierre. SHANNON--George E.,83, Broadcast Pioneer dies. George Shannon was President of CBS in the 70s and 80s, during the golden years of the "Tiffany Network." He oversaw all broadcast production facilities nationwide, all remote production including sports events and major news coverages, network distribution system, engineering and development. Countless Emmy Awards for engineering excellence were earned under his leadership and vision. Mr. Shannon, of West Islip, Long Island, passed on January 4, 2016. He was the beloved husband of the late Rita J. Shannon. He was the devoted father of Sharon Ann Fuentes, Barbara Ann Kelly and Michael T. Shannon and the cherished grandfather of six. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. KAISER--Walter, May 31, 1931 to January 5, 2016. Born in Bellevue, Ohio during the Depression, the son of a grocer, he became a page in the U.S. Senate in 1944 and then won scholarships to Philips Academy, Andover and Harvard, an institution he didn't leave until retirement. He graduated magna cum laude with highest honors in 1954, received his Ph.D. in 1960, and was made Professor of English and Comparative Literature in 1969. From 1988 to 2002 he served as Director of Villa I Tatti, the Harvard University Center for Italian Renaissance Studies in Florence. His leadership profoundly shaped I Tatti, and those were among his happiest years; he always felt that he truly belonged to the northern Mediterranean, especially to Greece and Italy. His love of learning and the arts gave color and depth to every aspect of his life. Few people have been more learned or more cultivated, wittier or more awake to beauty. Fewer still have had his genius for friendship. He was extraordinarily generous with his attention, and always finding opportunities for generosity where others wouldn't have seen them. He was the best of fathers. He is survived by his children, Miranda and David, and three granddaughters; by his brother, Bob; by his many godchildren; and by hundreds of others whose lives he enriched immeasurably, as the astonishing outpouring of grief and love from around the world since his death attests. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Walter Kaiser Fund for the Biblioteca Berenson at Villa I Tatti, Harvard University. 1/3 KAISER--Walter, May 31, 1931 to January 5, 2016. KAYE--Honorable Judith. The NYU School of Law mourns the passing of our distinguished alumna, the Honorable Judith Kaye '62. Judge Kaye, who served for 25 years on the New York Court of Appeals and was its Chief Judge from 1993 to 2008, was a trailblazer for women, a brilliant jurist, and a vocal advocate for legal reform. She was also a deeply committed member of the NYU Law community. In addition to serving as a trustee in the 1980s and '90s, she was an advisory board member of our Center on Civil Justice; a director of our Institute for Judicial Administration; and recipient of nearly all of our most distinguished awards for alumni achievement and service. We are grateful for her life and deeply saddened by her loss. NYU School of Law Trevor Morrison, Dean 1/3 KAYE--Honorable Judith. KAYE--Judith S. With heartfelt sadness, the Trustees and Administration of Barnard College mourn the passing of the Honorable Judith S. Kaye '58, who was a devoted alumna, a Barnard Trustee from 1995 to 2002, and again from 2008 to 2009, an active trustee emerita, and a member of the Athena Center Board of Advisors. In 1987, she received the College's highest honor, the Barnard Medal of Distinction, and in 2010, the Frederick A.P. Barnard Award for all she has done for women, for the rights of the individual, and for her alma mater. Barnard honors the memory of this extraordinary woman and extends its deepest sympathies to her family. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President 1/3 KAYE--Judith S. MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, to whom she was lovingly married for 57 years. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer and Audrey, and grandchildren Emily, Johnny, Henry, Tommy and Charlie, as well as her brothers, Alan and Jeffrey Reider. She graduated from Wellesley College and had a stellar career as a magazine editor. She received the National Magazine Award for her work at Good Housekeeping and was honored at a reception with President Clinton at the White House. She was fluent in five languages and was an avid world traveler with an adventurous spirit. She enjoyed playing tennis at the East Hampton Tennis Club and golf at the Noyac Golf Club as well as participating in two book clubs. Most of all she loved spending time with her family who greatly adored her and will miss her terribly. Funeral services to be held Friday January 8, 2016 at 2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3 MARK--Erika Reider, of New York City and East Hampton died on January 5, 2016 after a brief illness. KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. 1/3 KAYE--Judith. January 7. KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourn the passing of the Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals and the first woman to lead the state's judiciary. A passionate supporter of the performing arts, she was a Lincoln Center board member, where she made a lasting contribution as Chairman of the Legal Committee. Judge Kaye also served on the board of Lincoln Center Education and she was honored at our David Rubenstein Atrium Gala in 2013. Her wisdom, leadership and friendship inspired us daily. We offer our sincerest condolences to her children Luisa, Jonathan, and Gordon, their spouses and children, and to her many friends and former colleagues. Katherine Farley, Chairman Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. 1/3 KAYE--Hon. Judith S. CARLSON--Claudia, died at the Dawn Greene Hospice in her 59th year on January 6, 2016. Claudia was born in Bloomington, Indiana to Elof and Helen (nee Zuckerman) Carlson and raised in six college towns. She was an illustrator, graphic designer, book designer, cartographer, photographer, and poet. She wrote three books of poetry, co-edited one volume of poetry, and wrote and illustrated a children's book. She worked for Farrar, Straus and Giroux, Oxford University Press, and American Friends of Magen David Adom. She also was a founding member of River Writers of Manhattan. She received her BA at Stony Brook University. After her mother's death she was raised by her father and Nedra (nee Miller) Carlson with her younger siblings, Christina, Erica, John and Anders. With David Allen she had two children Natalie (nee Allen) Hardaker, and Caitlin Allen. She is also survived by her husband, playwright James Racheff. A memorial service is planned for early spring. Condolences can be sent to: claudiacarlson@gmail.com 1/3 CARLSON--Claudia, died at the Dawn Greene Hospice in her 59th year on January 6, 2016. SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3 SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. KRAVET--Stanley, 81, passed peacefully at home in Manhasset, NY, with his family and devoted wife Rhoda Kravet by his side. Born in 1934 in Brooklyn, NY to Rose and Morris Kravet, he graduated from Boys High and NYU School of Business, where he met his wife. He attended Brooklyn Law School on a full scholarship and after graduating he began working at Royal Abstract, a New York City title insurance agency. He spent over 45 years building Royal Abstract into a well known and successful company and welcomed his son Martin into the business in 1985. He was very well respected by all who knew him. Outside of his work he was involved in the rebuilding of the Jewish Center of Bayside Oaks, in Queens. He enjoyed golf and was an esteemed member of Engineers Country Club and Cold Spring Country Club. He and his wife spent winters at Boca West in Boca Raton, Florida where they were members of Boca West Country Club. He was a kind and proud man who was devoted to his family. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Rhoda, loving father to son Martin (wife Susan) and daughter Susan Pecker (husband Elliot) and his adored grandchildren, Justin, Rachel, Dylan and Caroline. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather and brother and he will be greatly missed. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, in New York City on Friday, January 8 at 12pm. 1/3 KRAVET--Stanley, 81, passed peacefully at home in Manhasset, NY, with his family and devoted wife Rhoda Kravet by his side. GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3 GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. BOULEZ--Pierre. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Pierre Boulez, one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. A legendary composer, conductor, musical philosopher and activist, Pierre Boulez was a visionary and trailblazing global force for modern music. Carnegie Hall was privileged to elect him an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and to appoint him as the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer's Chair from 1999 to 2003. Boulez made approximately 75 appearances at Carnegie Hall, conducting close to 60 performances on our stages, and his works have been performed on more than 80 programs. As an arts educator, he was inspirational-challenging audiences to explore a new aesthetic of music through his musical research center IRCAM, and, in the course of the Professional Training Workshops he led through Carnegie Hall's Weill Music Institute, offering profound insights to young musicians. Boulez's work in Paris served as an inspiration in the conception of Zankel Hall, the opening season of which included performances by Boulez with the Ensemble Intercontemporain. Pierre Boulez will be deeply missed by all of us at Carnegie Hall and by the entire artistic community, though his brilliant musical legacy and pioneering spirit will stay with us all. We express heartfelt condolences to his sister, Jeanne Chevalier Boulez, and brother, Roger Boulez, as well as their many children and grandchildren. Sanford I. Weill, President; Mercedes T. Bass, Acting Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3 BOULEZ--Pierre. KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3 KAYE--Judith. January 7. GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Gene; devoted children Paul, Judith Kingman, and Robert; grandchildren Alexander and Garrett Kingman and Michelle and David Glantz, and nephew Bruce Kauderer. A consummate gentleman, he was a World War II veteran, lawyer, founder of real estate development, investment and management firm, Windsor Properties, and esteemed patriarch of his extended family. His patience, wisdom, optimism, generosity and strong family values will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Laid to rest in Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York on December 28, 2015. 1/3 GLANTZ--Irwin L.,91, died peacefully at home on December 26, 2015 after a brief illness, with his loving family at his side. KAYE--Hon. Judith S. The Fordham Law community is deeply saddened by the death of Hon. Judith S. Kaye, former Chief Judge of the New State Court of Appeals. She was a great friend of Fordham Law School and its alumni, particularly those serving in the state and federal judiciary. Over the years, she wrote for the Fordham Law Review and other journals, and she inspired students, graduates, and alumni with her remarks at the school's diploma ceremony, conferences, and lecture series. The school honored her in 2002 with the Fordham- Stein Prize, which is presented annually to a member of the legal profession whose work embodies the highest standards of the legal profession. In 2012, she participated in a special conversation alongside retired Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that canvassed their concerns about the election of judges, the importance of civic education and involvement for lawyers, and their pathbreaking appointments as the first women to hold their respective judicial roles. In addition to her jurisprudence, her administrative impact will leave an indelible mark on the office of Chief Judge of the State of New York. We extend our deepest sympathy to her colleagues at Skadden Arps and her family. Matthew Diller, Dean Fordham Law School 1/3 KAYE--Hon. Judith S. SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. Siegel died January 6, 2016 due to complications from a bone marrow transplant for the treatment of Leukemia. Peter was born in New York City on March 24, 1950 and grew up in Great Neck, NY. He has a BA from the University of Mass. Amherst, and holds two masters degrees from the University of Chicago. He was a passionate sailor and resided in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Deborah and William Cosentino, seven cousins, as well as his very dear friends Dave Turner and Christine Benner. He is and will be greatly missed. We will be holding a memorial service for Peter this spring in New York City, time and location to be announced. 1/3 SIEGEL--Peter L. It is with heavy hearts, we announce that Peter L. LIBERTINI--Richard Joseph, actor, died January 7, after a two year battle against cancer. He was born nearly 83 years ago in Cambridge, MA to Esther and Rocco Libertini. He graduated from Emerson College and was partner with MacIntyre Dixon and Linda Segal in the uproarious act they named, "Stewed Prunes" which played in coffee houses in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago. His first Broadway play was in Woody Allen's "Don't Drink the Water." His last was in Allen's "Relatively Speaking" in 2011-12. Richard worked in a number of television series, and movies, most notably as the Guru in the film, "All of Me," and the crazy General in "The In-laws." He is survived by his son Richard, a musician, sister Alice Langone, brother Albert, brother-in-law Mike Langone, sister-in-law Catherine Dillon, cousin Mario Libertini of Abruzzi, Italy, beloved nieces and nephews, former wife, and friend Melinda Dillon, and many true and great friends. A memorial service will be held in the future. 1/3 LIBERTINI--Richard Joseph, actor, died January 7, after a two year battle against cancer. WIGDER--Harriet (Fein). We regret to announce the untimely passing of Harriet (Fein) Wigder. Harriet was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 23, 1930 to Betty and Victor Fein. She was a graduate of Hunter College and obtained a Master of Arts degrees from Teachers College, Columbia University. Harriet was an elementary school teacher in the New York City public school system. She had a special fondness for children, their education and integration into the mainstream of New York cultural life. Harriet was an early devotee of the fledgling State of Israel and visited Israel in her teenage years and many times thereafter. She was married to Dr. Bernard Wigder and they lived in Riverdale, New York for many years. They were actively involved in community charitable activities and were supportive of the Jewish Theological Seminary and the Riverdale Jewish Center. In retirement the Wigders lived in Pembroke Pines, Florida and continued their participation there in communal affairs. Bernard died in 2005. Harriet remained the beloved matriarch of her family and the extended Feinzeig clan. She passed away last Shabbat afternoon, January 2, 2016 with her immediate family in attendance. Harriet leaves her brother Jack, her sister-in- law Karin and her niece Shifra, who treasure her memory. Contributions in her name should be directed to the Hadassah Women's Organization. 1/3 WIGDER--Harriet (Fein). We regret to announce the untimely passing of Harriet (Fein) Wigder. BOULEZ--Pierre. The Directors of the Amphion Foundation, Inc. acknowledge with deep regret and sorrow the passing of Pierre Boulez, longtime friend and colleague of our founder, Elliott Carter. Their close relationship began in 1955 when Carter attended the premiere of "Le Marteau Sans Maitre" and continued without interruption until Carter's passing in 2012. Although he will be greatly missed by many, his stature as a preeminent composer and conductor, and his devotion to contemporary music, has created a permanent legacy which will continue to influence the development of music for many years to come. The Amphion Foundation, Inc. Virgil Blackwell, President James M. Kendrick, Secretary 1/3 BOULEZ--Pierre. HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. His name was Wiliam Joseph Hochswender III, but everyone knew him as Woody. For many, he was the lanky, redheaded and perennially boyish fashion and style reporter for The New York Times, Harper's Bazaar, Esquire and Golf. For others, he was an inspirational practitioner of Nichiren Buddhism: he brought comfort, joy and wisdom to many through his example, his guidance and his two books, "The Buddha in Your Mirror" and "The Buddha in Your Rearview Mirror." In Sharon, CT, where he had lived since 1993, he was known as a quirky character with memorable pickup trucks (his beautiful golden retriever, Lola, nearly always along for the ride) and a passion for swimming, biking and otherwise enjoying the beauty around him. For his daughter, Kate, he was her biggest cheerleader as well as the person who always encouraged her to set a high standard and then meet it. He adored her, and she adored him. A true journalist, Woody was interested in everything; for the past few years, he was able to travel widely and meet interesting people in the company of his girlfriend, Kirsten Jensen. His daughter and former wife, Cynthia, were glad that he was able to enrich his life and expand his horizons with Kirsten before his death, from a glioblastoma tumor, on December 31. For a full obituary and details of his January 17 memorial service in Lakeville, CT, go to his memorial website at www.forevermissed.com. 1/3 HOCHSWENDER--Woody, June 20, 1951, to December 31, 2015. WEISSMAN--Julia Zlabovsky, 98, died on October 15, 2015 after a brief illness. BROSS--Arthur, of Poughkeepsie, NY, died Wednesday, December 30, 2015 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was surrounded by his loving family, caregivers and grand dog. Art was born October 17, 1928 in Bronx, NY to the late Joseph and Bessie Bross and preceded in death by five siblings. He was 87 years young. Art served in the Army and Army Reserves, attaining the rank of 1st Lieutenant and he received a National Defense Service Medal. Never one to back down from a challenge, he worked full time while attending City College of New York for his B.S.M.E and M.S.M.E. degrees. Art was a Senior Engineer at IBM Microelectronics in Hopewell Junction, NY, author or editor of three books, and holder of 10 U.S. patents. He loved the country, gardening, birding, antiquing, and barbecuing, with a penchant for overcooked meats. Art was a beloved husband of the late Isabel Beth Bross for 47 years, a devoted father to his two daughters, Judy (Jeff) Bramson of Highland Park, IL and Jill Bross of Westhampton, NY. His two grandchildren, Alex and Nina Bramson were the loves of his life. Memorial donations can be made in Art's memory to the Alzheimer's Association. www.alz.org 1/3 BROSS--Arthur, of Poughkeepsie, NY, died Wednesday, December 30, 2015 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease. BERKOWITZ--Leonard, 89, Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Vilas Research Professor at the University of Wisconsin, died on January 3, 2016 in Madison, WI. Dr. Berkowitz was born in New York City on August 11, 1926. He received his bachelor's degree from NYU and his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan. He served in the United States Army during WWII. Dr. Berkowitz was on the faculty of the University of Wisconsin at Madison from 1955 to 1989. He also held visiting appointments at Stanford, Oxford, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. He was one of the pioneers in the experimental study of altruism but is, perhaps, best known for studying influences on aggressive behavior, including the effects of television and film violence. Dr. Berkowitz was the author of over 170 articles and books, and is one of the most frequently cited psychologists of the twentieth century. After his retirement, he continued to write in his field, submitting his last article for publication on November 1, 2015. He was an avid world traveler, collector of modern art, follower of world events and opera-goer. Dr. Berkowitz was predeceased by his first wife, Nettie, in 1975. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Norma, and two daughters, two stepsons, five grandchildren, two step-grandsons and a brother. A memorial fund has been established in his honor for the benefit of Psychology graduate students at the UW- Madison. Contributions to the Berkowitz Memorial Fund may be mailed to the University of Wisconsin Foundation, Attn: A. Kitslaar, 1848 University Ave, Madison, WI 53726. 1/3 BERKOWITZ--Leonard, 89, Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Vilas Research Professor at the University of Wisconsin, died on January 3, 2016 in Madison, WI. DELFINER--Henry, of Lexington, MA passed away January 3, 2016. Born in Vienna, Henry and his sister fled Austria on the day of the Anschluss, coming to the United States via Paris. He graduated from Amherst College in 1943, joined the Army, serving with the 88th Infantry Division in northern Italy. On May 2, 1945, acting as the translator for his commanding officer, Henry took the surrender of a whole German corps, including the First German Parachute Division. Decorated with the Bronze Star, he left the Army as a major. After the War, he was instrumental in reclaiming the family business from the Nazis, thereafter running the Herzmansky Department Store himself. He was also involved with the family business Greene Tweed of Kulpsville, PA through most of his adult life. He received a Ph.D. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and taught at Tufts University as a professor of International Relations. His class on "Understanding International News," which he taught in the Experimental College at Tufts was very popular. After retiring from Tufts in 1987, he continued to write scholarly articles about the history of central Europe. In 1999, concerned with a lack of balance in political views in academia, he joined with Hadley Arkes, Edward N. Ney Professor in American Institutions at Amherst College in establishing the Colloquium on the American Founding, a twice-yearly weekend series of lectures and seminars where well-known national figures and influential conservative speakers were invited to present their views. He will be remembered for his kindness and his extraordinary generosity. Beloved husband of Barbara (Schudawa) Delfiner. Devoted father of Hannah Delfiner, Michael Delfiner and his wife Tracey, and Ruth Delfiner and her husband Paul Cooke. Loving brother of Charlotte Sperber. Cherished grandfather of Allon Bloch and his wife Annelise, Benjamin Delfiner, Rebecca Delfiner and her fiance Tom, and Emma Cooke. Proud great-grandfather of Alexander Bloch. 1/3 DELFINER--Henry, of Lexington, MA passed away January 3, 2016. SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. Annette, who turned 90 December 2, graduated with a B.S. from Columbia University School of Nursing and an M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. Starting her career in New York City for the Visiting Nurse Service, Annette then spent many years in Pennsylvania as a school nurse for the Pennsbury School System. All who knew Annette recognized that she was a caring and skillful nurse and loving mother, aunt, grandmother, sister, daughter, niece, cousin and friend. Annette cared deeply for the people in her life and we all will miss her warm smile, concern, and love. Her family expresses their heartfelt appreciation to her skillful, kind, loving and warm caregivers, Kimberly Barrett and Jacques Clervil. A memorial service is being planned for early 2016. The family knows that Annette would appreciate contributions in her memory to the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing 215-898-484 nursing.upenn.edu/friends giving, Columbia University School of Nursing, 866-GIFTSYS, or nursing.columbia.edu/giving, a charity benefiting Israel or any charity of your choice. 1/3 SQUIRE--Annette C. of Boynton Beach, FL, devoted and beloved wife for almost 60 years of the (late) Albert Squire, daughter of the late Irving and Bella (nee Lehman) Cohen, sister of the late Molly Gershen, mother of Jeffrey and Judi Squire, loving grandmother of Evan and Emma Squire, and aunt to Robert and Joe Gershen, Susan Stoll, Susan Albright and Laura Stamm, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 8, 2015 at Delray Medical Center following a stroke on December 7. SWEENEY--Anne J. 85, passed away in Los Angeles on Friday, December 11, 2015. She was preceded in death by her adoring husband, Donald E. Sweeney, Sr., and her brothers, James (in infancy), Thomas, James, William, and Edward, and her sisters Claire Rose Taber and Marie Becker. She was born on March 1, 1930, in Wilkes-Barre, PA to James J. and Marie O'Connell Tormay. She moved to Onondoga Hill in Syracuse, NY in 1939. She was a communicant of St. Michael's Church in Syracuse. She received her Bachelor of Science degree from the State University of New York Teacher's College at Oswego in 1951, where she was President of the Newman Club. Her great passion in life was teaching and her favorite people were children. She completed her student teaching in Baldwinsville, NY and began her formal career in Liverpool. She moved to the Hudson Valley in the mid fifties and taught in Hudson, NY, and later in the Kingston Consolidated School District for 18 years. She taught second grade at both the Elisha M. Brigham Elementary School and Chambers Elementary School. Her students will remember her ability to do all of the voices when reading "Charlotte's Web" aloud to the class, lessons in "SC" (self control) and her mantra, "Life is Choices." She also taught evening adult education with her husband at John F. Kennedy Elementary School and was CCD instructor at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, NY, where she also served as a Eucharistic Minister. She is survived by her three children, Anne M. Sweeney and her husband Philip H. Miller of Los Angeles, Donald E. Sweeney of Kingston, and Rosemary Sweeney Hanczor and her husband, Robert Hanczor of San Diego. She also leaves seven adoring grandchildren - Christopher and Rosemary Miller, Michaela and Shelagh Sweeney, and Catherine, Elizabeth and Brigid Hanczor, as well as a cousin, Rita Tormay of Yonkers, NY and many nieces and nephews. A Funeral Mass was held on December 16 at St. Monica's Catholic Church in Santa Monica, CA, followed by a burial service at Holy Cross Cemetery in Culver City, CA. She was born on March 1, 1930, in Wilkes-Barre, PA to James J. and Marie O'Connell Tormay. She moved to Onondoga Hill in Syracuse, NY in 1939. She was a communicant of St. Michael's Church in Syracuse. She received her Bachelor of Science degree from the State University of New York Teacher's College at Oswego in 1951, where she was President of the Newman Club. Her great passion in life was teaching and her favorite people were children. She completed her student teaching in Baldwinsville, NY and began her formal career in Liverpool. She moved to the Hudson Valley in the mid fifties and taught in Hudson, NY, and later in the Kingston Consolidated School District for 18 years. She taught second grade at both the Elisha M. Brigham Elementary School and Chambers Elementary School. Her students will remember her ability to do all of the voices when reading "Charlotte's Web" aloud to the class, lessons in "SC" (self control) and her mantra, "Life is Choices." She also taught evening adult education with her husband at John F. Kennedy Elementary School and was CCD instructor at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, NY, where she also served as a Eucharistic Minister. She is survived by her three children, Anne M. Sweeney and her husband Philip H. Miller of Los Angeles, Donald E. Sweeney of Kingston, and Rosemary Sweeney Hanczor and her husband, Robert Hanczor of San Diego. SULSER--Fridolin, M.D. December 2, 1926 - January 3, 2016. Dr. Fridolin Sulser, who devoted his life to understanding the physiological basis of mental disorders and their treatment, died on January 3, 2016 at age 89, surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his brother, Emil Sulser of Maienfeld, Switzerland, wife, Johanna Mooser Sulser, and children Anna (Sulser) Newton, Adrian Sulser, Daniel Sulser, and Bettina (Sulser) Bryant, along with eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Dr. Sulser was born in Grabs, Switzerland and grew up in the town of Maienfeld, amidst his beloved Swiss Alps. He graduated from the Humanistische Gymnasium in Chur in 1947, attended Medical School at the University of Basel (pre-clinical) and the University of Zurich (clinical), graduating with an M.D. in 1955. He served as a medical officer in the Swiss Army, married the love of his life, Johanna, and moved with his wife and infant daughter to begin a position as assistant professor at the University of Bern. The family's great American adventure began in the fall of 1958 when Fridolin accepted a post-doctoral fellowship in Neuropsychopharmacology at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, M.D. Four years later, he went to Burroughs Wellcome Research Labs in New York as Head of Pharmacology. In 1965 he joined the Vanderbilt University Medical School Faculty as professor and Director of the Pharmacology Research Center, becoming a Professor Emeritus of the University in 2000. Dr. Sulser received many honors during his research career, including the prestigious Anna-Monika Prize, and was a Fellow and President of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology as well as a Fellow of the Collegium International Neuro-Psychopharmacolo- gium. He was a very proud father and grandfather, who celebrated the childrens' successes as they pursued their chosen paths. He found inspiration in nature, literature, philosophy and the fine arts. Memorial Service: January 24 at 4pm at the Greater Nashville Unitarian Universalist Church, 374 Hicks Road, Nashville, TN 37221. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to the scholarship fund at Vanderbilt School of Medicine "In Memory of Dr. Fridolin Sulser" (Vanderbilt Gift Processing, PMB 407727, 2301 Vanderbilt Place, Nashville, TN 37240-7727) or to the Friends of Radnor Lake "In Memory of Fridolin Sulser" (www.radnorlake.org). 1/3 SULSER--Fridolin, M.D. December 2, 1926 - January 3, 2016. KAYE--Judge Judith S. With great sadness the Yeshiva University community mourns the loss of Judge Judith S. Kaye, who was granted an honorary degree from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in 1993. Judge Kaye was the first woman to become Chief Judge of New York, serving with great distinction for 16 years, longer than any other chief judge in the state's history. The daughter of Jewish immigrants from Poland, Judge Kaye's distinguished legacy demonstrates her belief in equality before the law, and her commitment to break down barriers in the legal field, and in society at large. Judge Kaye is remembered for the exceptional warmth and generosity she displayed to the Cardozo community, especially in her interactions with students. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President, Yeshiva University Melanie Leslie, Dean, Cardozo School of Law 1/3 KAYE--Judge Judith S. O'BRIEN--Mrs. Elva L. of Manhattan, NY died on January 7, 2016. She would have been 97 years of age in February. Mrs. O'Brien was born on February 13, 1919, in West Springfield, Massachusetts to Henry and Mary (Choquette) Brassard. On May 30, 1944, she married Lawrence F. O'Brien, Jr., at St. Joseph's Church in Springfield. Mr. O'Brien went on to twice serve as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as a senior White House aide to Presidents John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, and as Commissioner of the National Basketball Association. They were married for 46 years before Mr. O'Brien passed away in New York City in September of 1990. Mrs. O'Brien resided in Washington, D.C., from 1961-1973, before moving to New York City in 1973 where she lived at 860 U.N. Plaza for more than 40 years. She spent summers at her home in the town of Cotuit on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. A thoughtful and generous philanthropist, Mrs. O'Brien was involved in the Archbishop's Christmas Appeal/Catholic Charities of New York and also supported the New York Public Library, the Cotuit Library Association in Barnstable on Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and the Environmental Film Festival in Washington, D.C. Mrs. O'Brien was instrumental in creating the "Lawrence F. O'Brien Gallery" exhibit space within the National Archives in Washington, D.C. She was fiercely loyal to her family and friends, possessed a keen sense of humor and was a person inclined to speak her mind. Her passion for books and for reading was legendary. Mrs. O'Brien is survived by her beloved son Lawrence F. O'Brien III, and his wife Helen (Powell) O'Brien of Washington, D.C., and her two cherished grandsons Luke O'Brien and Peter O'Brien both also of Washington, D.C. Funeral services will be private. A reception in fond remembrance will be scheduled at a future date. The family requests that any donations in memory of Mrs. O'Brien be made to the New York Public Library/Audio Books Division or Catholic Charities of New York. 1/3 O'BRIEN--Mrs. Elva L. of Manhattan, NY died on January 7, 2016. BERG--Ivar E. (1929-2016), an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, who made important contributions to the study of higher education, labor markets and industrial sociology, died on January 1, 2016. Dr. Berg's classic book, Education and Jobs: The Great Training Robbery (1970) cast doubt on economists' assertions that people with more education earn more because they are more skilled and productive; instead, employers frequently hire people to work in jobs that do not make use of their education. His book played a major role in a landmark civil rights decision by the U. S. Supreme Court, Griggs vs. Duke Power Company (1971) and was credited with providing the bases of the theory of market signaling, for which Akerlof, Spence, and Stiglitz shared the 2001 Nobel Prize in Economics. Among his many honors, he was elected a Fellow of the International Academy of Management, which cited him as "one of the seminal figures in the sociological study of labor markets and the founder of economic sociology." Born January 3, 1929 in Brooklyn, NY, he earned his AB at Colgate and his doctorate at Harvard. He served in the U.S. Marine Corps, retiring as a major, and on the faculties of Columbia and Vanderbilt, in addition to Penn. Dr. Berg, author of more than 70 articles and chapters and dozen books, leaves a wife, Sharon (Calli) Berg, a son and daughter-in-law, Geoffrey and Amy Berg, and stepsons Tim Smallwood (and his wife, Staci Smallwood) and Jim Smallwood (and his fiance, Catta Keith). 1/3 BERG--Ivar E. KAYE--Judith S. The Historical Society of the New York Courts mourns the loss of our founder and guiding spirit, Judith S. Kaye. We recognize and celebrate that no one has had a more profound, positive impact on our court system. She was New York's first female, and longest serving, Chief Judge, and used her matchless energy and wisdom, heart and soul, to reshape the courts to improve the lives of countless people. She pioneered court innovations based on the premise that the legal system exists to serve the people with fairness and sensitivity. For this she was beloved, nationally and internationally. She neither sought nor basked in the accolades, acknowledging them with a shy smile and a handwritten note combining modesty and gratitude. She could be hilariously funny, but never at anyone else's expense. It is fitting that her memorial service will be held at Lincoln Center as the arts were important in her life, and she could be heard singing in the courthouse corridors. Judith once said she has a 5 to 9 job, arriving at 5am (often with grandmother photos to exchange with maintenance staff) leaving at 9pm, and yet she was always able to be there, undistracted, for her family and friends. Though as a historical society we focus on figures from the past, we were so fortunate to have had one of the nations' leading lights in our midst. She battled her illness with courage and dignity. It seemed to us that the day of her passing would somehow never come. But she was, after all, human. The Historical Society of the New York Courts 1/3 KAYE--Judith S. KAYE--Judith. The law clerks to Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye deeply mourn the loss of our beloved Chief. A brilliant jurist, scholar, writer, thinker, she served as mentor to us all, our teacher, confidante, cheerleader and friend. Her passion for justice, her commitment to equal rights, her insistence that everything could be made better, powered by boundless energy and a never-ending cascade of new ideas, will continue to inspire us always. Each of us is sustained by treasured memories of the times we spent together, by uproarious laughter born of her mischievous wit. We all feel so lucky to have worked with her, our lives are richer for having known her, and we will miss her terribly. 1/3 KAYE--Judith. The law clerks to Chief Judge Judith S. KAYE--Judith. January 7. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our colleague and friend Judith Kaye. Before joining our New York appellate litigation and arbitration practice in 2009, Judith spent 25 years on the bench of the New York Court of Appeals, including the last 15 as its Chief Judge. The first woman to serve on New York's highest court, Judith earned a national reputation for her pioneering opinions and court reforms. She wrote seminal opinions on such issues as the death penalty, same-sex marriage, education and state constitutional rights while leading innovative changes to the New York court system, including the establishment of specialized courts to focus on issues of drug addiction, domestic violence and mental health. As Chief Judge, Judith created the Adoption Now program, helped establish the Center for Court Innovation and co-chaired the ABA Commission on the American Jury. She retired from the bench in 2008, having served longer than any Chief Judge in state history. At Skadden, Judith helped numerous clients navigate complex issues of New York law. She also served as a trustee of the Skadden Fellowship Foundation and continued her advocacy for families and children, including through her service as the chairwoman of the Permanent Judicial Commission on Justice for Children. Judith graduated from Barnard College ('58) and NYU School of Law ('62), where she was one of 10 women in a class of nearly 300. Judith is survived by her children, Luisa, Jonathan and Gordon, and seven grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am (doors open at 9:15), Monday, January 11, at the David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center. 1/3 KAYE--Judith. January 7. PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3 PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3 PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Prior to that, she resided in Scarborough, NY and Washington, DC. Mrs. Caron worked for IBM in New York, New Jersey and Washington, DC for 35 years, retiring as a manager in 1991. She enjoyed reading and was very active at Orchard Cove. Mrs. Caron was the sister of Catherine A. Sheehan of Brentwood, NY and the late John J. Flanagan. DUTTON--Pauline Barbara, of Kinderhook, NY and Canaan, CT passed away on January 10 at the age of 90. Born in New York City, she was the adored wife of the late Ben Joseph Dutton, an inspirational and devoted mother to Deborah Dutton Minton and Pamela Barbara Dutton and grandmother of Sebastian Frugone and Alexandra Frugone. GREASON--Mary Twomey. The entire Marymount Manhattan College community mourns the loss of Mary Twomey Greason. Mary Twomey Greason graduated magna cum laude from Marymount Manhattan College in 1986 with a Bachelor of Arts in art history and went on to a life of service for the College. Mary encouraged alumni to become involved and give back to the college, and demonstrated tremendous generosity and leadership in her work on the Board of Trustees from 1995 to 2004 and again from 2005 to 2014. She lit up every room she entered and was a friend to all. Mary's commitment to Marymount Manhattan and her dedication to the college's students, faculty, and staff will always be remembered. Services: visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY, Tuesday, January 12th from 3:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Funeral Mass at 11:00am on Wednesday, January 13th, at Our Lady of Peace Church, East 62nd St. between Second and Third Avenues. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested contributions to the Mary Twomey Greason Endowed Scholarship at Marymount Manhattan College. Kerry Walk, Ph.D., President, Marymount Manhattan College Hope Knight, Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, Marymount Manhattan College 1/3 GREASON--Mary Twomey. PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. Present, born April 3, 1934, passed away on January 12th from complication of Parkinson's Disease. He was 81 years old. His passing will be deeply mourned by Jane Werner Present, his wife, partner, lover and best friend of more than 59 years, his three children, their spouses, and four grandchildren, Tracy Present, Stephanie, Michael, Billy and Katherine Podalak, Douglas, Susan, Adam and Margot Present, and his sister Judy Present Liss; his friends, associates and the thousands of lives he touched during his 50 years of practice. Dan graduated from Syracuse University Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa in 1955 and State University of New York Downstate College of Medicine, Magna Cum Laude, in 1959. He completed an internship, medical residency, Gastroenterology residency and GI Fellowship at Mt. Sinai Hospital, and entered private practice in 1964, where he quickly began to focus his attention on the management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. He was the recipient of the first research award given by the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America. Dan brought clinical trials into clinical practice. His first paper was accepted for publication in 1966. He subsequently published 329 papers. At the time of his retirement, his publications had been cited more than 15,000 times. During his 54 years at Mt. Sinai, he served as President of both the Association of the Attending Staff and the Alumni Association for which he received the coveted Jacobi Medallion for Conspicuous Service to the Alumni. Dan received every award in his field including the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine Distinguished Service Award, The American Gastroenterology Association Distinguished Clinician Award, Master of the American College of Gastroenterology, The WiIIiam Dock, M.D. Master Teacher Award in Medicine State University of New York, the Janssen Award for Outstanding Achievement Award in Clinical Gastroenterology, the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America Lifetime Achievement Award and the George Arents Award for Excellence in Medicine, the highest achievement awarded by Syracuse University. He is generally recognized as having pioneered the way Crohn's disease is treated. More than any recognition, Dan loved taking care of his patients. He loved them and they returned that love many times over. His joy came from sparing his patients the pain, discomfort, and humiliation of inflammatory bowel disease by finding the right combination of medications and thoughtful creativity. He fought against surgery if there was a possible medical solution. He talked with his patients for many more hours than any HMO wouId have allowed. He sat at their bedside and visited them late at night, he celebrated when they felt better. Nothing made him happier than a college student being able to return to school, or a young adult feeling well enough to plan a wedding or bear a child. He loved teaching young Gastroenterologists and, along with a grateful patient, created the Present-Levison fourth year fellowship in Clinical GI, which allowed the brightest young men and women to spend a post-graduate year learning clinical GI at Mt. Sinai. These fellows now care for IBD patients all over the world. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12pm at "The Riverside," 180 West 76th St., New York. Contributions in Dan's memory may be made to the Present-Levison Fellowship at Mt. Sinai, and sent to the Division of Gastroenterology, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1069, New York, New York 10029. 1/3 PRESENT-- Dr. Daniel H. A brilliant, creative, and abundantly loved giant has left us. Dr. Daniel H. HAGOPIAN--Louis Thomas. Of Vero Beach, FL and Darien, CT, died after a short illness in his Florida home on January 9, 2016 at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Joanne Kelly Hagopian; his daughter Susan Goddard and sons Thomas and Matthew; nine grandchildren; his sister Helen Geovjian; and more than 40 members of his extended family. Lou thought himself to be one of the luckiest men in the world, with a wife and family who loved him and whom he loved dearly, parents he respected and adored and a career he both enjoyed and succeeded in beyond his wildest hopes. As the son of parents who fled to the United States after their families were killed in the Armenian Genocide, he felt that he truly lived the American Dream and loved this country for it. Lou served in the US Navy during World War II and graduated from Michigan State University after the War. His career started in the auto business, but his skills in marketing and communications soon led him to a successful career in advertising with the oldest agency in the US, NW Ayer. He led NW Ayer for over 25 years, including the last ten as Chairman and CEO. During his tenure, Ayer was selected Agency of the Year and developed numerous iconic advertising campaigns with taglines such as "A Diamond is Forever" and "Be All That You Can Be." He also was Chairman of the Advertising Association of America and a founding member of the innovative Partnership for Drug-Free America. Lou was a man of style with an enormous heart, tremendous charm and a wicked wit. He loved to serenade his wife, Joanne, with "Misty" or "My Funny Valentine" whenever given the slightest excuse (and often without). An avid and excellent golfer for over 70 years, he started as a caddy at the Pine Lake Country Club outside of Detroit and ended as a member of the Royal & Ancient Golf Club in St. Andrews (where he won the Seniors Tournament at the age of 86). Services will be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Darien, CT at 10:30am on Saturday, January 16. A memorial service will also be scheduled for friends and relatives in Vero Beach in the next several weeks. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a memorial donation be made to Indian River Habitat for Humanity, www.irchabitat.org. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. An online guest book is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3 HAGOPIAN--Louis Thomas. DIAMOND--Michael H. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of dear friend and former partner, Michael H. Diamond. A highly regarded lawyer who made a tremendous impact on the litigation field in Los Angeles and beyond, Mike joined Milbank in 2000 as partner and head of the Litigation Group in the Firm's Los Angeles office. Prior to joining Milbank, he spent 23 years at Skadden, Arps, where he opened and expanded the firm's Los Angeles office. After retiring from Milbank in 2007, Mike founded a successful consulting and expert witness firm, MHD Group. During his career, he advised numerous corporations and their officers, directors and shareholders, on complex and high-profile disputes. Mike was also dedicated to pro bono work, applying his legal skills to a wide range of matters. These included the merger of Brandeis-Bardin Institute with the University of Judaism, which formed the American Jewish University, and his successful defense of journalists in a case related to the 2000 Democratic National Convention, which earned him recognition from the ACLU Foundation of Southern California. He held degrees from Brown University and Columbia University Law School. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mike's wife, Marilyn, his four children Seth, Cory, Beth and Debra and ten grandchildren, and to his entire family. 1/3 DIAMOND--Michael H. SMYLIE--The Reverend Robert F.,87 and a resident of Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls, NJ, passed away on Saturday, December 19, 2015. He was born in Memphis, Tennessee; grew up in St. Louis, Missouri; and spent most of his adult life living in Englewood, NJ and working in New York City. A graduate of Washington University, Robert was an ordained Presbyterian minister with a Masters in Divinity and Theology from Princeton Theological Seminary and a Masters in Philosophy from Columbia. A lifelong student of international affairs, world traveler, and advocate for peace and human rights, he had spent 27 years with the Presbyterian Church USA's Peacemaking Program in several capacities before retiring as the Director of its United Nations Office in 2002. He had also served as a US Navy chaplain, taught at the University of Florida as an Assistant Professor in Social Sciences, and had been a Visiting Fellow at New College, University of Edinburgh in Scotland. Robert was a widower; his wife, Yuri Yamamoto, was a concert pianist and teacher. He is survived by his sons, Mark and John. A memorial service is scheduled for 11am, Saturday, January 16, at First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Memorial Scholarship established by the family of his grandniece, Rachel G. Smylie, at the charity Geography of Hope. 1/3 SMYLIE--The Reverend Robert F.,87 and a resident of Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls, NJ, passed away on Saturday, December 19, 2015. BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II, then graduated from New York University (1948), Phi Beta Kappa, and entered the graduate program at Harvard (Ph.D. in English Language and Literature, 1954), where he wrote a prize-winning essay on Shakespeare. He spent his entire teaching career at Tufts University (1954-84), serving twice as chair of the Department of English. He published a number of essays in scholarly journals, a popular introduction to Shakespeare, and he served as General Editor of The Signet Classic Shakespeare, a paperback series (one play per volume) that is widely used in colleges and universities. He was also the author or co-author of several widely used textbooks-on argument (with Hugo Bedau, late of the Tufts Department of Philosophy), art, composition, drama, and literature, including "A Short Guide to Writing about Art" (now in its 11th edition), and "Introduction to Literature" (16th edition). In 1963, he and William Burto (his partner since 1952, deceased 2013) developed an interest in Japanese art, especially calligraphy, and they went on to build a collection that was exhibited in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Freer Gallery, the Harvard Art Museum, and the Museum of Fine Art, Houston. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog by Miyeko Murase, "The Written Image" (2002), to which Barnet and Burto contributed two essays, one on collecting, the other on looking at calligraphy from a Western point of view. (After Burto's death their collection was divided among the first four of these museums.) He and Burto also wrote "Zen Ink Paintings" (1982) as well as several essays on Japanese art. As a teacher of English literature, he was familiar with a good deal of writing about death. Among the favorite passages he carried in his head-he could not understand why some educators disparage "rote memory"-were Shakespeare's "Golden lads and girls all must/As chimney sweepers come to dust." and this epitaph by Sir Henry Wotton (1568-1639), "Upon the Death of Sir Albert Morton's Wife": "He first deceased; she for a little tried/To live without him, liked it not, and died." (Barnet said, shortly after the death of his partner, that Wotton's lines came to his mind every day, and that he regretted, every day, his inability to re-enact them.) He leaves his sister-in-law Saretta Barnet, a niece and three nephews and their spouses, nine grandnephews and nieces, a great-grandnephew and niece, and his longtime friend, Morton Berman. Most of his estate was bequeathed to a scholarship fund at Tufts, in honor of his parents, Philip and Esther Barnet. By his wish there will be no services. 1/3 BARNET--Sylvan, born in Brooklyn, New York, on December 11, 1926, died at home in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on January 9, 2016. SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. Denning, M.D., she was an internationally recognized pediatrician and one of the leading experts in the field of Cystic Fibrosis research and care. Carolyn Rebecca Denning was born on May 30, 1927 in Detroit, MI. She was raised in Franklin, KY and graduated from University of Kentucky in 1947. She graduated from Tulane University School of Medicine with an M.D. degree in 1952. After her internship and residency, she completed a pulmonary fellowship in 1957 at Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center where she worked with Dr. Dorothy Andersen and the group that originally described CF. She spent the remainder of her career in the Metropolitan New York City area. From 1963-1977, she served as Director of Cystic Fibrosis and Pediatric Pulmonary Disease Centers of Babies Hospital, at Columbia Presbyterian. In 1977, she founded the Cystic Fibrosis, Pediatric Pulmonary and GI Center at St. Vincent's Hospital, and served as its Director until retiring in 1995. For over 40 years she cared for hundreds of patients with CF and formed lasting bonds with their families. She trained many of the CF caregivers who are practicing throughout the world today, upholding her standards of care and compassion. She is survived by her husband of 59 years, Peter R. Scaglione, M.D., four sons and seven grandchildren. The family will receive friends at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, on Friday, January 15 from 6-9pm and Saturday, January 16 from 12-4pm (3pm Remembrance). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research Fund for Cystic Fibrosis, 455 Oradell Ave., Oradell, NJ 07649. A memorial service will be held at later date. 1/3 SCAGLIONE--Carolyn, M.D.,of Englewood, NJ died on January 10, 2016, age 88. Known professionally as Carolyn R. PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. Present, M.D., a beloved physician who, in a five-decade career at Mount Sinai, was at the forefront of research into the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Dr. Present was the first researcher to show the effectiveness of an immunosuppressant, 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), in fighting Crohn's disease. When Dr. Present published his results in The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) in 1980, it changed the lives of thousands of Crohn's patients. Later, he studied the use of cyclosporine for severe steroid- refractory ulcerative colitis, and demonstrated that it could help avoid or delay colectomies in many of these seriously ill patients. In a third breakthrough in the late 1990s, Dr. Present studied cA2, also known as infliximab, an anti-tumor necrosis factor antibody, and showed, in another seminal paper in the NEJM, that it could help close fistulas in Crohn's patients. Early in his career at Mount Sinai, he was mentored by Henry D. Janowitz, M.D., for whom the Division of Gastroenterology is named. Dr. Present was also a talented clinician who cared for thousands of patients over his career. Over a decade ago, he and his wife, Jane, established an endowed fellowship at Mount Sinai to train graduates from outside institutions to become experts in the care of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Dr. and Mrs. Present also maintained a foundation for clinical research of IBD. Upon his retirement from Mount Sinai in 2014, the foundation donated its principal in support of The Susan and Leonard Feinstein Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Center at Mount Sinai. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jane and their children, Douglas, Stephanie, and Tracy, at this difficult time. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, M.D. Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3 PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolific ground-breaking research in Gastroenterology. In the tradition of Drs. Crohn, Ginsberg, and Oppenheimer, he continued Mount Sinai's pioneering work in the study of inflammatory bowel diseases. Through his investigations, an important class of medications was added in treating Colitis and Crohn's Disease. He was awarded the prestigious Jacobi Medallion in 1991 and was a great supporter of the institution. A long term AAS board member, he served as President of the physicians' organization from 1979-1980. Dr. Present will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the School and Hospital, and his commitment to excellence. His legacy will continue in the generations of students he taught and the many lives he touched. We extend condolences to his wife Jane and his entire family. Eric Neibart, M.D., President Mark Reiner, M.D., Vice President Amy Weinstein, Administrator 1/3 PRESENT--Daniel H.,M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend.
