WEIDENFELD--Lord George. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of a giant, a committed philanthropist, world-renowned publisher of authors including Vladimir Nabokov, articulate advocate of the Jewish people and fearless defender of the Jewish State of Israel. George Weidenfeld grew up in Vienna and fled Austria after the Nazi takeover in 1938. Because he was saved by a Christian family, George never forgot that his life was spared by Christians and just last year, he created a foundation to rescue thousands of persecuted Christians in the Middle East. This man never forgot his debts and always repaid them. As an immigrant during World War II, George became an integral part of the BBC World Service and broadcast reports in several languages. In 1969, Queen Elizabeth acknowledged Britain's appreciation and knighted him, followed by a life peerage in the House of Lords in 1976. Last April, at the age of 95, Lord Weidenfeld was awarded the WJC's Theodor Herzl Award in London and became an honorary vice-president of the World Jewish Congress. There are few people in the entire world who have spoken out with more courage against injustice. Our dear friend George was one. He was one of the most inspiring and accomplished figures of the 20th and 21st centuries. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Annabelle, daughter Laura, grandchildren and great grandchildren. We will miss him deeply. World Jewish Congress President Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman of the Governing Board David de Rothschild, Treasurer Chella Safra 1/3 WEIDENFELD--Lord George. FEINBERG--Jacob. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Jacob Feinberg dies at 87. The Feinberg Family and the Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation mourn the loss of the organization's co-founder, Jacob Feinberg. A CPA with Brout and Company and BDO, Jack later became a pioneer with his wife Arlene advancing the cause of bone marrow donor registration throughout the United States and abroad for the benefit of patients battling blood cancer. His efforts made possible bone marrow transplants for thousands of patients in need. The world is a better place thanks to Jack, a true hero, and his memory will live on through the lives he and Arlene saved together. He was the loving father of Jay, Steven, Edward of blessed memory and daughter-in-law Sheryl; loving grandfather of Shauna, Michelle and Skylar; brother of Robert and sister-in-law of Marty. Jack will be missed by the entire Gift of Life organization that he and Arlene created, and his countless friends and loving family. Contributions in Jack's memory may be made at www.giftoflife.org. 1/3 FEINBERG--Jacob. Bone Marrow Registry co-Founder Jacob Feinberg dies at 87. CHILDS--Kirsten Anne, died of cancer at age 72 on January 13, 2016. Survived by spouse, Alexander Grinnell. She was born in Inverness, Scotland, and attended Edinburgh University. She began her career in London and was selected to collaborate with Skidmore Owings & Merrill in NYC. In 1971, Her marriage to Russell Childs kick started Armstrong Childs Associates. Her career as an interior designer flourished - culminating with Croxton Collaborative (1985-2015). She all but wrote the book on green design: Served on the US Green Building Council's LEED Steering Committee and chaired the Environmental Quality Technical Advisory Group for all LEED rating systems through 2004. Additionally, she was a founding member of LEED for Commercial Interiors, and received the 2010 ASID Designer of Distinction Award. Kirsten was a wonderful story teller, vivacious reader, bird lover, and operavore. She was a member of New York's Century Association and Waltz Society. She enjoyed travel with her dear friends and son, was a gleaming grandmother, and shall be remembered by her treasured family: Alex, Aaron, Natasha, Alexandra, Theodore, Delailah, Sebastian, Skye, and a plentitude of friends/colleagues Contact KACMem orial@gmail.com for memorial service information. Send condolences to her son, Aaron Childs, 6 Old Mill Lane, Rose Valley PA 19063. BOROWITZ--Rabbi Eugene Bernard, a teacher of generations of rabbis and Jewish leaders, adoring and devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, professor of modern Jewish thought and education at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, scholar and author of 19 books and innumerable articles over seven decades, founder of Sh'ma Magazine, and proclaimed "bearer of light" by the Union of Reform Judaism passed away peacefully in his home on January 22, 2016. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Estelle Covel Borowitz and is survived by his children Lisa Borowitz, Drucy Borowitz and Philip Glick, and Nan and Andrew Langowitz; their children Zoey Glick and Matthew Swerdlin, Zachary Glick, Noah Langowitz and Monikah Schuschu, Emily Langowitz, and Joshua Langowitz; and great-grandson Lewis Swerdlin. ZIELENZIGER--Dr. Ruth, who helped change how Conservative Jews in America are taught the Bible, and inspired some of Israel's most enduring poetry of love while a young woman, died Thursday at the RiverWalk independent living facility of the Hebrew Home in the Bronx, one day shy of her 93rd birthday. Awarded her Doctorate of Hebrew Literature at age 66, Dr. Zielenziger was instrumental in creating the curriculum for teaching the books of Genesis and Exodus in Conservative Judaism at the Melton Research Center of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York City. The Melton program emphasized critical inquiry and the study of Bible for character education. She was a proponent of studying the creation myths and texts of other Middle Eastern cultures in order to better understand the context in which the Bible was written. Born in London, the daughter of Leo and Lola Herrmann, ardent Zionists, she grew up in Jerusalem before the founding of the Jewish state, and served as an ambulance driver and chauffeur in the British Army during World War II, where her fluency in Hebrew, English and German was invaluable. After the War, she attended the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, where she met a German emigre and fellow student, Yehuda Pfeuffer, whom she renamed Yehuda Amichai. Amichai went on to become Israel's most celebrated poet, and the first drafts of many of his most enduring poems were composed as letters exchanged between the two. Amichai's letters to Dr. Zielenziger are now archived at Ben Gurion University in Israel. She moved to New York in 1947, to study at the Teachers Institute of the Seminary. While in New York she met and subsequently married Eric W. Zielenziger, a German Jewish survivor of the Holocaust who escaped the Nazis by living underground in Amsterdam for more than two years. They had two children. For 34 years, Dr. Zielenziger taught education at the Jewish Theological Seminary, after teaching for many years in Hebrew schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Before relocating to Riverdale in their later years the Zielenzigers lived primarily in Freeport and Great Neck, NY. She is survived by her sons David, of Great Neck, and Michael (Diane Abt) of Oakland, CA and Manhattan and a brother, Dr. Gabriel Herrmann of Jerusalem. 1/3 ZIELENZIGER--Dr. Ruth, who helped change how Conservative Jews in America are taught the Bible, and inspired some of Israel's most enduring poetry of love while a young woman, died Thursday at the RiverWalk independent living facility of the Hebrew Home in the Bronx, one day shy of her 93rd birthday. WASHBURN--Seth H. Seth Harwood Washburn, executive, musician, fly fisherman, civil rights advocate and beloved patriarch, died on January 17 in Bath, Maine. He was 94. Seth was born in Kansas City, MO on October 24, 1921, the son of Henrietta DeSelding and Rt. Reverend Benjamin Washburn, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. He married Janet Higginbotham in 1944. Seth attended Dartmouth College, and earned BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from MIT. After serving in the Navy during World War ll, Seth joined Bell Laboratories where he spent his entire career and co-authored "The Design of Switching Circuits," a seminal text in his field. Seth was a fierce advocate for civil rights and fair housing. He was recognized by the Association of Black Laboratories Employees as a "visionary executive, skillful leader, and man of dignity and grace." In 1984, Seth and Janet fulfilled their love for the ocean and the working coast of New England by retiring to Bath. Janet died in 1987. Seth was an accomplished musician, playing piano, flute, and recorder, and had a passion for jazz. His life-long devotion to fly-fishing included tying his own flies for over 70 years. He loved his Newfies, Labs, and Maine Coon cats - and a strong martini and a good cigar. He is survived by five children, ten grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Seth Washburn was an extraordinary man and will be deeply missed by all who knew him. 1/3 WASHBURN--Seth H. GREENFELD--Marvin, on January 21, 2016, of New York City, formerly of Alexandria, VA, died peacefully shortly before his 91st birthday. Devoted husband to the late Renee E. A WWII Veteran, he had a long professional career in electrical engineering and management, loved jazz and classical music-he was an outstanding trumpet player-and was an unreformed punster. Our father also frequently contributed to dozens of charitable organizations. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, January 26, 2016, 12pm at Judean Memorial Gardens Chapel, 16225 Batchellors Forest Rd., Olney, MD. Interment will immediately follow in Judean Memorial Gardens Cemetery. 1/3 GREENFELD--Marvin, on January 21, 2016, of New York City, formerly of Alexandria, VA, died peacefully shortly before his 91st birthday. SHEPPARD--Annamay, passed away in her sleep at her home in West Orange, New Jersey on December 30, 2015. She was 88.5 years old. For anyone who knew her or her work as a civil rights attorney, activist, and Rutgers Law School professor, it is clear that it's difficult to summarize who she was or the effect she had on others. She was magnetic, funny, serious, smart, and strongly believed in the work she did. People loved her deeply. Her community stretched wider than even we, her family, knew. Thank you for being a part of Annamay's life. 1/3 SHEPPARD--Annamay, passed away in her sleep at her home in West Orange, New Jersey on December 30, 2015. She was 88.5 years old. VANDERSALL--Thornton M.D. The Department of Psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital mourns the passing of our former Chairman, Thornton Vandersall MD on January 8, 2016. From 1974 to 1988, Dr. Vandersall's leadership was characterized by a commitment to resident education, sensitive patient care and faculty development. A board-certified pediatrician, psychiatrist and child psychiatrist, he also initiated a Child Psychiatry Division at North Shore. Dr. Vandersall received his MD degree from Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, his pediatric training at Bellevue and New York Hospitals, and his psychiatry and child psychiatry training at St. Luke's Medical Center. He achieved the rank of Emeritus Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College. Engaged in both his local medical community and national psychiatry organizations, Dr. Vandersall was recognized as a life member of the Nassau County Medical Society, the Medical Society of the State of New York, and the American Medical Association; and as a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. He influenced the careers of many psychiatrists and the lives of countless patients and families through his high clinical standards, his strong physician values, and his thoughtful gentlemanliness. John M. Kane, M.D. Chairman, Department of Psychiatry North Shore University Hospital/ Long Island Jewish Medical Center/ Hofstra Northwell School of Medicine 1/3 VANDERSALL--Thornton M.D. The Department of Psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital mourns the passing of our former Chairman, Thornton Vandersall MD on January 8, 2016. POLLNER--Martin. The family of Martin Pollner mourns the passing of its devoted husband, father, grandfather and brother. In addition to his service to his family, Martin provided more than half a century of service to his country and to the legal profession, serving several United States presidents. He held senior positions with the United States government, including Deputy Attorney General under Robert F. Kennedy and Deputy Assistant of the Treasury and Director of Law Enforcement under Secretaries of the Treasury David Kennedy, John Connally and George Schultz. He helped develop civil rights legislation and developed and coordinated law enforcement policy within the Treasury Department, including the IRS, Customs, Secret Service and Interpol. In addition to service on various Cabinet committees, Martin headed the U.S. Delegation to several Interpol General Assemblies and, after returning to private practice, he was appointed by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as the U.S. representative to the International Narcotics Control Board of the United Nations, a position he held for several years. Over the years, Martin received numerous honors and awards, including the Townsend Harris Medal in 2005 and the Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2007. After serving as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Martin, in private practice, advised and represented individuals, including CEO's of major corporations as well as numerous luminaries, and companies; investigated corporate misconduct; and untangled complex tax issues, workouts and bankruptcies. Notwithstanding a stellar legal career, nothing delighted him more than his family. He is survived by his wife Valerie, his sons Daniel and Richard, and their spouses, Melissa and Deb, granddaughters Gabriella, Rebekah and Lexi, and his brother Philip. He was entirely unique, and we will miss him. For those who wish to honor his memory, we ask that donations be made to The Rogosin Institute, www.rogosin.org/donate, The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, or Cardiovascular Institute Fund of Mt. Sinai. 1/3 POLLNER--Martin. The family of Martin Pollner mourns the passing of its devoted husband, father, grandfather and brother. EPPLER--Jerome C. Investment professional, passed away on December 16, 2015 at his home in Denver, Colorado. He was born on March 16, 1924 in Englewood, New Jersey, to William E. and Aileen V. Eppler and was a 50 year resident of Morris County, NJ. He was educated at the Peck School, Berkshire School, Rice University, Texas A&M and graduated with an MBA from Wharton (University of Pennsylvania) in 1949. Prior to attending Wharton, Jerry served in the US Navy as a Lieutenant JG on USS La Porte, and later served on the staff of Admiral Louis Denfeld (Chief of Naval Operations) in Washington, DC. Jerry began his investment career at Equitable Securities in Houston before joining the New York brokerage firm of Cyrus J. Lawrence & Sons in 1952, where he became their youngest partner. In 1961 Jerry created Eppler & Company as a private, independent advisory and investment firm focused on managing portfolio assets for a number of family groups including the Bass and Richardson families of Wichita Falls, the Harrington family of Amarillo, the Murchison family of Dallas, and the Vickers family of Wichita and Denver. Eppler & Company advised its clients on both control and non-control investments in numerous public and private companies, including venture capital investments, leveraged buyouts and proxy contests as an activist investor in an era when many of these investment strategies were not widely deployed. Through his work at Eppler & Company, Jerry was active in the management and governance of some of America's major companies. In the transportation sector, he played a role in the establishment of the New York Central Railroad and later served as a director of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad (1965-1969). In addition, Jerry helped to found US Airways through the acquisition of regional carriers including Mohawk Airlines and Lake Central Airlines. Jerry was a longstanding director of Swift & Company and had an important role in the transformation of Swift into Esmark, Inc. between 1965 - 1990, creating one of America's leading conglomerates with a business portfolio that included: Swift Meats, International Playtex, Avis Rent a Car, Vickers Energy and Trans Ocean Oil. Jerry was a director of Recognition Equipment Company, inventor of the bar code and digital reading technology as well as Tessco Technologies Inc. a major electronics distribution company (1982-2007). In the entertainment world, Jerry was the chairman of United Screen Arts from 1966-1973. In finance, Jerry was Chairman and CEO of ISI Corporation (1967-1977), owner of the Life Insurance Company of California (innovator of the universal life insurance product), Windsor Life (U.K), and World Wide Life Assurance Co. (U.K.) which, together, were later sold to EF Hutton. Jerry was a long serving director of Telecredit Inc., a technology-enabler of the credit card industry (later acquired by Equifax) and was a director of the First National Iron Bank of Morristown New Jersey. Jerry was a limited partner of Alex Brown & Sons (Baltimore, MD) from 1982-1984, and a principal in Olympic Capital Partners, a Seattle based investment group (1995-2000). In addition to his corporate efforts, Jerry was an active philanthropist, particularly supporting education and the arts. Jerry would remain active with Wharton throughout his career and served as the first head of Wharton's Alumni Association (1972-1986). In addition, he was a co-founder of the New York Society of Security Analysts. He was a lifelong supporter of Middlebury College in Vermont and served as a trustee of Drew University (Madison, NJ) from 1966-1967. He was a longtime board member of the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences (Morristown, NJ, 1954-1976) and served on the Board of the Metropolitan Opera Association (New York City, 1980-1982). Jerry was a member of the Industrial Advisory Committee of the University of California (San Diego, 1978-1993) and served on the Board of the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation (La Jolla, CA). In his later years, he was the founding Chairman of the Global Leadership Council in the College of Business at Colorado State University, serving as its first Chairman (2002-2004) and as a member (2002-2012). Jerry will be remembered by his many friends and family as a quintessential venture capitalist with a keen business vision and strong entrepreneurial spirit. Jerry is survived by his wife, Debora Nye Eppler, his five children (Stephen, Randy, Margaret, Elizabeth Vidmar and Edward), eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be laid to rest in a family plot in Mendham, New Jersey. Share your memories of Jerry by visiting the guestbook link. - See more at: www.horancares.com 1/3 EPPLER--Jerome C. GANZ--Arnold R.,age 90, a resident of Westport, CT, passed away peacefully at his home on January 21, 2016. Mr. Ganz was born in New York City, son of the late William and Irene Ganz, and was a United States Army Veteran who served during World War II. He was a recipient of a Purple Heart and Bronze Star. He attended Biarritz American University and NYU majoring in business administration. Mr. Ganz was President of Pervel Ind., a subsidiary of Bemis Corporation, until his retirement in 1990. He is survived by his beloved wife of 64 years, Enid W. Ganz, his devoted children; Austin (Cheryl), Harrison (Heidi), and Andrea (Robert Vogel), and adored grandchildren Evan, Bradford, and Jordan. Mr. Ganz was predeceased by his sister, Lenore Epstein. Funeral services will take place on Monday, January 25, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel 14 Coleytown Road Westport, CT with interment at Temple Israel Cemetery, Richards Avenue in Norwalk. Memorials to the American Liver Foundation. 1/3 GANZ--Arnold R.,age 90, a resident of Westport, CT, passed away peacefully at his home on January 21, 2016. MURPHY--Arthur W.,93, Professor Emeritus of Columbia Law School, died on January 16th. He was a graduate of Boston Latin School, Harvard University, and Columbia Law School (Class of 1948). A veteran of the 17th Airborne Division in WWII, he joined the faculty of Columbia Law School in 1963 after stints at the U.S. Department of Justice and in private practice. Professor Murphy taught until four years ago, becoming, at 89, the oldest active professor in the history of the Law School. Survived by wife Jean, children Lois, Rachel, and Paul; sons- in-law Peter and James; grandchildren Matthew, Elizabeth, Keith, Julia, Alexander, and Nicholas; and great- grandchildren Kayla, Autumn, and Zoe. A memorial at Columbia Law School will be announced as soon as plans are completed. 1/3 MURPHY--Arthur W.,93, Professor Emeritus of Columbia Law School, died on January 16th. RYAN--Dr. James H.,85. Pioneering psychiatrist, and long time Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at the Columbia College of Physicians & Surgeons, died at home in East Hampton on December 28th. Dr. Ryan played a key role in introducing the use of video to psychiatric education, helping to shape the curriculum for several generations of New York State medical residents. Over his nearly 60 year career, Ryan also maintained an active private practice, first in New York, and then too in East Hampton. Born in 1930 in Albion, NY, Ryan didn't fit the typical mold of psychotherapist. He rode high school football stardom to Yale, where he started as quarterback in his senior year, and also punter and kick-off receiver. Invited to training camp with the Cleveland Browns, Ryan opted instead for Harvard Medical School, and a life beyond football. In addition to former students, patients, and colleagues, Ryan is survived by his loving family: Wife Lisa Eyer Ryan, daughter Justine Ryan, sons Maxwell and Oliver Ryan, and granddaughter Ursula, as well as by his brother Maury Ryan of Providence, RI. 1/3 RYAN--Dr. James H.,85. FREDENBURGH--Harold, architect of emblematic tall buildings on skylines across the country, died on January 21, 2016 after a year-long battle with cancer. He was 82 years old. After earning a Master of Architecture degree from Yale University, Fredenburgh worked for a quarter century at I.M. Pei & Partners, where he was an associate partner and design principal. He established his own office, Fredenburgh Wegierska-Mutin Architects, in 1990. In his work with the Pei firm and in independent practice, each of his buildings marked its setting with iconic forms and distinctive public spaces, from a master planned waterfront promenade in Dubai to the iconic CenTrust Tower in Miami, Texas Commerce Tower in Houston, and First Interstate World Center, the tallest building west of Chicago, which provides a memorable centerpoint to the vast horizontal landscape of Los Angeles. Harold Fredenburgh also made major contributions to the design of the John Hancock Tower in Boston. Fredenburgh's efforts in landmark preservation and planning policy contributed to shaping New York City. For two decades his leadership in planning and design review in his home community of Bronxville, New York, was instrumental in preserving the unique character of a landmark residential village while allowing it to meet the challenges of contemporary needs. He was a guiding voice on the Scholarship and Brunner Award Committees of the American Institute of Architects/New York Chapter, a member of the Planning and Urban Design Committee, and a founding member of the Society of Architectural Historians. An unusually well read and scholarly architect, he was an accomplished international lecturer on design and urban planning issues, and was widely regarded in both the university and in the office as a dedicated teacher and ardent advocate of young professionals. As a consequence of his experience with the design of tall buildings, in 1998 he was elected one of four American members of the Russian Academy of Architecture and Building Sciences. He was elevated to Fellowship in the American Institute of Architects in 2014. Harold Fredenburgh will be very missed by his daughter Audrey Mateer, son-in-law Robert Williams, Anna Mutin, friends and colleagues. 1/3 FREDENBURGH--Harold, architect of emblematic tall buildings on skylines across the country, died on January 21, 2016 after a year-long battle with cancer. WEIDENFELD--Lord George The America-Israel Friendship League expresses its great sorrow at the passing of Lord George Weidenfeld. His wisdom, experience, good will and warm friendship can never be replaced and will never be forgotten. His activities in support of efforts to resolve the challenges of international affairs involved intimate contact with world leaders at the highest levels. He will especially be remembered for guiding the renewal of German participation in world affairs which accelerated Germany's acceptance in the councils of peace and constructive dialogue. His commitment to the survival and success of Israel in world affairs can be matched by few participants in international diplomacy. We send our sincere condolences to Lady Weidenfeld and his adoring family. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Honorary President; Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman; Ambassador Dan Gillerman, Chairman of Israel Board; Daniella Rilov, Executive Director; Ruby Shamir, Executive Director, AIFL Israel and Director of International Operations; Dr. Charlotte K. Frank, Chair, Executive Committee; Ira J. Greenblatt, Treasurer; Peter J. Halasz, Secretary James S. KENNEDY--Michael John, on January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. Civil rights lawyer who fought for the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments. Mr. Kennedy, whose career as both a civil liberties and criminal attorney began in California in the 1960s, successfully defended Black Panther Huey Newton on manslaughter and murder charges in Oakland. In San Francisco, he won acquittal for all seven young Mexican Americans, Los Siete de la Raza, charged with murdering a police officer in the city's Mission District. And when Jimmy Mitchell, co-owner of San Francisco's notorious O'Farrell Theatre-which journalist Hunter S. Thompson called 'The Carnegie Hall of Public Sex'-was accused of killing his brother Artie in a drunken rage, Mr. Kennedy succeeded in having the charge reduced from murder in the second degree to manslaughter. In Illinois he represented Rennie Davis, a member of the Chicago Eight accused of conspiracy and inciting a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention and served as Mr. Davis's lawyer before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C. He also represented Bernardine Dohrn who belonged to 1960s radical group, The Weathermen. Other of his clients belonged to the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, the most famous member of which was Timothy Leary, LSD guru to a generation. In Lincoln, Nebraska, Mr. Kennedy won acquittal for a Penobscot Native American charged with assaulting FBI agents at Wounded Knee. Perhaps his most famous trial and certainly the most time consuming-it still remains the longest criminal jury trial in U.S. Federal Court history-was The Pizza Connection; the name came from accusations of drug money laundering through pizza parlors in New York City. When the U.S. Attorney put two warring mafia families on trial, the case played out like a drama between the Capulets and the Montagues with Mr. Kennedy retained as chief council representing one of the godfathers, Sicilian mob boss Gaetano Badalamenti. Wire taps were the basis for charges against six Americans raising money in New York to buy weapons for the IRA in Ireland. As lead council, Mr. Kennedy won an acquittal for all six men. He also won clemency from New York Governor Mario Cuomo for Jean Harris, the private girls' school headmistress who was in prison for the notorious murder of her lover, Scarsdale Diet doctor Herman Tarnower. Mr. Kennedy worked on only one divorce case in his career and although the settlement was sealed, reliable sources reported that Ivana Trump was very pleased. There were many pro-bono cases about which no one has written. And there were many times when people from all walks of life, the high, the low, and the undocumented, sought Kennedy's advice privately and many times he privately reached out to connections, sometimes in the government, sometimes in the underworld. As general council to High Times Magazine for 41 years, Mr. Kennedy and his friend, the magazine's founder, the late Tom Forcade, sought to subvert prohibition of marijuana. When a reporter recently asked Mr. Kennedy how he kept High Times out of trouble for so long, he replied simply that he had never asked or allowed them to do anything illegal but added: "At High Times we will never forget what was done in the name of law enforcement to our scarred arrestees, and those who still rot in prison for daring to try to enjoy themselves peacefully and harmlessly." Mr. Kennedy was the consummate gentleman, with a quick Irish wit and a quick Irish temper. But he very rarely raised his voice, being the personification of Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy: Speak softly but carry a big stick. The romance between Michael Kennedy and Eleanora, his wife of forty-seven years, is the stuff of fairy tales. Marrying after love at first sight, they never spent a night apart and sometimes signed their names as one word. Although not an attorney, Mrs. Kennedy was her husband's most trusted associate and confidant working entirely behind the scenes on every case, becoming an unofficial voir dire expert. The couple eschewed the label 'socialite' but could be seen often at benefits for Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, the Central Park Conservancy and the United Nations. They gave as many parties as they attended, a number of which were chronicled in New York Magazine and the New York Social Diary. When not working or traveling, Mr. Kennedy spent his time between New York City, his Hamptons home Kilkare, his old Key West cottage in West Palm Beach and his house in Ireland's Black Valley. Michael John Kennedy, who died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, was born in the state of Washington in 1937. After boarding school in Washington, he attended University of California at Berkeley and Hastings Law School. Besides his wife Eleanora, he leaves his daughters Anna Safir and Lisa Kennedy, his son Scott Hamilton Kennedy, three granddaughters and two grandsons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday from 2-4 and 6-8pm. The funeral service will be held on Thursday at 10am at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue. 1/3 KENNEDY--Michael John, on January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. Civil rights lawyer who fought for the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments. Mr. Kennedy, whose career as both a civil liberties and criminal attorney began in California in the 1960s, successfully defended Black Panther Huey Newton on manslaughter and murder charges in Oakland. In San Francisco, he won acquittal for all seven young Mexican Americans, Los Siete de la Raza, charged with murdering a police officer in the city's Mission District. And when Jimmy Mitchell, co-owner of San Francisco's notorious O'Farrell Theatre-which journalist Hunter S. Thompson called 'The Carnegie Hall of Public Sex'-was accused of killing his brother Artie in a drunken rage, Mr. Kennedy succeeded in having the charge reduced from murder in the second degree to manslaughter. In Illinois he represented Rennie Davis, a member of the Chicago Eight accused of conspiracy and inciting a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention and served as Mr. Davis's lawyer before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C. He also represented Bernardine Dohrn who belonged to 1960s radical group, The Weathermen. Other of his clients belonged to the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, the most famous member of which was Timothy Leary, LSD guru to a generation. In Lincoln, Nebraska, Mr. Kennedy won acquittal for a Penobscot Native American charged with assaulting FBI agents at Wounded Knee. Perhaps his most famous trial and certainly the most time consuming-it still remains the longest criminal jury trial in U.S. Federal Court history-was The Pizza Connection; the name came from accusations of drug money laundering through pizza parlors in New York City. When the U.S. Attorney put two warring mafia families on trial, the case played out like a drama between the Capulets and the Montagues with Mr. Kennedy retained as chief council representing one of the godfathers, Sicilian mob boss Gaetano Badalamenti. Wire taps were the basis for charges against six Americans raising money in New York to buy weapons for the IRA in Ireland. As lead council, Mr. Kennedy won an acquittal for all six men. He also won clemency from New York Governor Mario Cuomo for Jean Harris, the private girls' school headmistress who was in prison for the notorious murder of her lover, Scarsdale Diet doctor Herman Tarnower. Mr. Kennedy worked on only one divorce case in his career and although the settlement was sealed, reliable sources reported that Ivana Trump was very pleased. There were many pro-bono cases about which no one has written. And there were many times when people from all walks of life, the high, the low, and the undocumented, sought Kennedy's advice privately and many times he privately reached out to connections, sometimes in the government, sometimes in the underworld. As general council to High Times Magazine for 41 years, Mr. Kennedy and his friend, the magazine's founder, the late Tom Forcade, sought to subvert prohibition of marijuana. When a reporter recently asked Mr. Kennedy how he kept High Times out of trouble for so long, he replied simply that he had never asked or allowed them to do anything illegal but added: "At High Times we will never forget what was done in the name of law enforcement to our scarred arrestees, and those who still rot in prison for daring to try to enjoy themselves peacefully and harmlessly." Mr. Kennedy was the consummate gentleman, with a quick Irish wit and a quick Irish temper. But he very rarely raised his voice, being the personification of Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy: Speak softly but carry a big stick. The romance between Michael Kennedy and Eleanora, his wife of forty-seven years, is the stuff of fairy tales. Marrying after love at first sight, they never spent a night apart and sometimes signed their names as one word. Although not an attorney, Mrs. Kennedy was her husband's most trusted associate and confidant working entirely behind the scenes on every case, becoming an unofficial voir dire expert. When not working or traveling, Mr. Kennedy spent his time between New York City, his Hamptons home Kilkare, his old Key West cottage in West Palm Beach and his house in Ireland's Black Valley. Michael John Kennedy, who died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, was born in the state of Washington in 1937. After boarding school in Washington, he attended University of California at Berkeley and Hastings Law School. BOUSVAROS--George M.D.,of Larchmont, NY passed away on January 19, 2016 after a brief illness. He was 86 years old. He was born in Thessaloniki, Greece, the only child of Athanasios and Glykeria Bousvaros. He graduated with the highest honors from the University of Athens Medical School, completed postgraduate training in cardiology in London and Canada, and immigrated to the United States in 1966. During his illustrious career as a physician, he was Chief of the divisions of cardiology at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Albany and Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan, and Professor of Medicine at Albany Medical School and the New York Medical College. After giving up his administrative duties, he continued to serve the people of New York as a cardiologist at Lincoln Hospital until he became ill. He was an outstanding husband, father, physician, teacher, and human being. He is survived by his wife Olga, two children Dr. Athos Bousvaros and Maria Tollefson, their spouses Dr. Margaret Lotz and Dr. Terry Tollefson and three grandchildren Sophia, George and Byron. COOPER--Peter Alan, 84, of Southold, NY, died peacefully at home after a short illness on January 18, 2016. He was a dedicated Cornell University alumnus and active in Phi Gamma Delta. After his retirement as Senior Executive Vice President from Sperry & Hutchison, he purchased and ran Sound Spars in Port Washington, NY. He retired to Southold and wintered in St. Thomas, USVI. He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Jean Thompson Cooper, and survived by his daughters Beth Kubinec (John) of Lancaster, PA and Susan Hodge of Warwick, RI, as well as sister Diane Nelson of Delaware, OH, numerous grandchildren and great- grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Eastern Long Island Hospital Foundation. www.de friestgrattan.com. 1/3 COOPER--Peter Alan, 84, of Southold, NY, died peacefully at home after a short illness on January 18, 2016. SISKIND--Beth, (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), on the morning of January 25, 2016 in her New York City home. Born Beth Diana Mohel August 10, 1940, she spent her first 18 years in New Bedford, MA, graduated from New Bedford High School and earned a bachelor's degree at Skidmore College (1962). A high- light of her time at Skidmore was an 11-week trip to Europe's Festivals of Art and Music which she financed through her successful investments in the stock market beginning at the age of 13. While raising her two boys in Scarsdale, Beth earned a Master's degree from the New School of Social Research. Beth was a dedicated mother, wife and grandmother. A lover of the arts and education, she relished being an angel for plays on Broadway and her most passionate charity work included efforts on behalf of Brandeis University, and Skidmore College. She will be greatly missed by husband Donald, sister Judith Hertz, sons Steven and Edward, their wives Moira and Lucinda and grandchildren Leila, Samuel and James. A service in her memory will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY at 12pm on Thursday, January 28. 1/3 SISKIND--Beth, (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), on the morning of January 25, 2016 in her New York City home. HOUGHTON--Rev. Alanson. The Reverend Alanson Bigelow Houghton died peacefully at his home in Pawleys Island, SC on Sunday, January 24th. He was 85 years old. Alan was born August 3, 1930 in Corning, NY to the late Amory Houghton Sr. and Laura Richardson Houghton. Alan earned multiple degrees including a Master of Business Administration from Harvard University and a Master of Divinity from New York Theological Seminary. Alan spent the early part of his career in business, where he worked for the Corning Glass Works. He then found his true calling and became an ordained Episcopal priest. He served at a number of different churches including Church of the Epiphany (New York City, NY), Christ Episcopal Church (Shaker Heights, OH), Church of The Heavenly Rest (New York City) and St. Stephens Episcopal Church (Charleston, SC). Alan felt strongly about public service and giving back to his country. One of his proudest accomplishments was becoming a United States Marine. Alan also had a passion for philanthropy, and he particularly enjoyed starting and supporting charitable programs in the communities in which he lived. Lastly, Alan loved to write. He was a published author who enjoyed writing cards, prayer books and letters to the editor. Alan was preceded in death by his beloved wife Billie Fisher Carr Houghton, his sister Laura Houghton Beer, and stepsons John Thomas Fisher Carr and Oscar C. Carr III. He is survived by his siblings Elizabeth Weinberg, Amory Houghton Jr., and James Richardson Houghton; his children Alexander Stewart Houghton, Alanson Bigelow Houghton III, Hope Houghton Newell and John Carter Houghton; his stepchildren Blanche Carr Symons, Scott Carr Adams and E'Lane Carr Tipton; and 19 grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Holy Cross Faith Memorial Episcopal Church in Pawleys Island, SC at 10am EST on Saturday, January 30th. Sign a guest book at www.mayer funeralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the National Parkinson Foundation or a charity of your choice. 1/3 HOUGHTON--Rev. Alanson. WALRATH--Dale Robert, of Manhattan, NY and formerly Wilton, CT, died on December 31, 2015 at home, at the age of 94. He was a World War II veteran, Mad Man, and devoted husband and father, who succumbed to Alzheimer's after a 12-year dignified struggle. An exemplar of the Greatest Generation, he was raised on a farm in Ohio, graduated from Ohio Wesleyan on scholarship, enlisted in the Army in 1943, and fought on the Western Front throughout Germany, receiving the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart before his honorable discharge in 1945. He moved to Connecticut in 1956, embarking on a 33-year career on the creative side with J. Walter Thompson in Manhattan. During his tenure at Thompson he helped develop the "Built Ford Tough" campaign and pioneered broadcast shoots in California. He was the most selfless of men, active in the community post-retirement, while caring for an ailing spouse for years. Survivors include his son Christopher Bret and daughter Rosalind Anne, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren, Margot, Victoria and Amanda. His courage, dignity, sacrifice for others, vitality, kindness, and extraordinary decency are treasured by all who knew him. 1/3 WALRATH--Dale Robert, of Manhattan, NY and formerly Wilton, CT, died on December 31, 2015 at home, at the age of 94. TUGGLE--Robert. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of its Director of Archives, Robert Tuggle, an invaluable member of the company whose passion for opera defined his life. He served as Director of Archives for more than 34 years, overseeing its many activities including the Archives Database, an exhaustive online compendium with detailed information on every performance in the company's 133-year history. Before coming to the Met, he worked in the education department of the Metropolitan Opera Guild for decades, beginning in 1957 when he was 24 years old. He was the author of The Golden Age of Opera and, at the time of his death, was at work on a biography of soprano Kirsten Flagstad. We extend our sincerest condolences to all those who knew and admired Bob, and whose lives were touched by his work. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3 TUGGLE--Robert. KENNEDY--Michael John. On January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. Civil rights lawyer who fought for the First, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments. Mr. Kennedy, whose career as both a civil liberties and criminal attorney began in California in the 1960s and culminated in 2009 as Special Advisor to the President of the United Nations, Miguel D'Escoto. He successfully defended Black Panther Huey Newton on manslaughter and murder charges in Oakland. In San Francisco, he won acquittal for all seven young Mexican Americans, Los Siete de la Raza, charged with murdering a police officer in the city's Mission District. And when Jimmy Mitchell, co- owner of San Francisco's notorious O'Farrell Theatre- which journalist Hunter S. Thompson called 'The Carnegie Hall of Public Sex'-was accused of killing his brother Artie in a drunken rage, Mr. Kennedy succeeded in having the charge reduced from murder in the second degree to manslaughter. In Illinois he represented Rennie Davis, a member of the Chicago Eight accused of conspiracy and inciting a riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention and served as Mr. Davis's lawyer before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C. He also represented Bernardine Dohrn who belonged to 1960s radical group, The Weathermen. Other of his clients belonged to the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, the most famous member of which was Timothy Leary, LSD guru to a generation. In Lincoln, Nebraska, Mr. Kennedy won acquittal for a Penobscot Native American charged with assaulting FBI agents at Wounded Knee. Perhaps his most famous trial and certainly the most time consuming-it still remains the longest criminal jury trial in U.S. Federal Court history-was The Pizza Connection; the name came from accusations of drug money laundering through pizza parlors in New York City. When the U.S. Attorney put two warring mafia families on trial, the case played out like a drama between the Capulets and the Montagues with Mr. Kennedy retained as chief council representing one of the godfathers, Sicilian mob boss Gaetano Badalamenti. Wire taps were the basis for charges against six Americans raising money in New York to buy weapons for the IRA in Ireland. As lead council, Mr. Kennedy won an acquittal for all six men. He also won clemency from New York Governor Mario Cuomo for Jean Harris, the private girls' school headmistress who was in prison for the notorious murder of her lover, Scarsdale Diet doctor Herman Tarnower. Mr. Kennedy worked on only one divorce case in his career and although the settlement was sealed, reliable sources reported that Ivana Trump was very pleased. There were many pro-bono cases about which no one has written. And there were many times when people from all walks of life, the high, the low, and the undocumented, sought Kennedy's advice privately and many times he privately reached out to connections, sometimes in the government, sometimes in the underworld. As general council to High Times Magazine for 41 years, Mr. Kennedy and his friend, the magazine's founder, the late Tom Forcade, sought to subvert prohibition of marijuana. When a reporter recently asked Mr. Kennedy how he kept High Times out of trouble for so long, he replied simply that he had never asked or allowed them to do anything illegal but added: "At High Times we will never forget what was done in the name of law enforcement to our scarred arrestees, and those who still rot in prison for daring to try to enjoy themselves peacefully and harmlessly." Mr. Kennedy was the consummate gentleman, with a quick Irish wit and a quick Irish temper. But he very rarely raised his voice, being the personification of Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy: Speak softly but carry a big stick. The romance between Michael Kennedy and Eleanora, his wife of forty-seven years, is the stuff of fairy tales. Marrying after love at first sight, they never spent a night apart and sometimes signed their names as one word. Although not an attorney, Mrs. Kennedy was her husband's most trusted associate and confidant working entirely behind the scenes on every case, becoming an unofficial voir dire expert. The couple eschewed the label 'socialite' but could be seen often at benefits for Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, the Central Park Conservancy and the United Nations. They gave as many parties as they attended, a number of which were chronicled in New York Magazine and the New York Social Diary. When not working or traveling, Mr. Kennedy spent his time between New York City, his Hamptons home Kilkare, his old Key West cottage in West Palm Beach and his house in Ireland's Black Valley. Michael John Kennedy, who died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, was born in the state of Washington in 1937. After boarding school in Washington, he attended University of California at Berkeley and Hastings Law School. Besides his wife Eleanora, he leaves his daughters Anna Safir and Lisa Kennedy, his son Scott Hamilton Kennedy, three granddaughters and two grandsons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Wednesday from 2-4 and 6-8pm. The funeral service will be held on Thursday at 10am at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue. 1/3 KENNEDY--Michael John. On January 25, 2016 at age 78 of cancer. FRANGOS--Eugenia Striphas, on January 21, 2016, of Forest Hills Gardens, NY. Beloved wife of James and devoted mother to Alexandra Frangos and George (Caroline). Loving grandmother to James and John. DRAZEN--Ruth Yorkin. We mourn the loss of Ruth Yorkin Drazen-mother, filmmaker and pioneer in genetics-who died quietly in her sleep on Monday evening at the age of 97. Ruth was born in Washington, PA on May 15, 1918, the daughter of Jesse Sachs Yorkin and Maurice A. Yorkin. Ruth adored classical music from early childhood on, studying piano at the Curtis School of Music with Henry Kaufman. In 1938 she married fellow Curtis student, Mario Berini, and they moved to New York City, where Mario began his career as a tenor with the Met. Their only child, Anton, died in infancy of a rare genetic disease, and Ruth's grief sparked her interest in curing genetic illnesses. She spent years working tirelessly as executive director of The Muscular Dystrophy Association and The National Genetics Foundation. When her second husband, New York attorney Jerome Drazen, died of prostate cancer in 1988, she developed an abiding passion for the subject of humanism in medicine, expressing it through the making of documentary films, which she continued to create into her early nineties. Her first film, "When Doctors Get Cancer," was a sensitive look at doctors treating other doctors, in the hope that it might make more humane the care that physicians gave, when they were able to observe themselves as cancer patients. Five other award-winning films followed, most of them shown on PBS. They included, "The Choice is Yours," the inspirational life of the great psychiatrist, Victor Frankl, "A Wayfayer's Journey; Listening to Mahler;" "Notes From the Edge, the Diary of Peter J. Morgan, M.D.," an intimate narrative of the last two years of the life of a 29-year old physician diagnosed with cancer, and "Healing Through Humanism," a five DVD teaching series devoted to the practice of compassionate medicine. Ruth was an intellectual and spiritual inspiration to everyone she touched, and will be sorely missed. Ruth is survived by a son, Myron Drazen and daughter-in-law, Lucille; a sister, Martha Yorkin Berman; two step-sons, Michael and Roger Drazen and seven grandchildren, Julie, Debra, Jacob, Dylan, Emily, Kate and Zoe Drazen. She was predeceased by a son, Anton Berini, as well as brother Alan "Bud" Yorkin; husbands Mario Berini and Jerome Drazen. Memorial service will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., in Manhattan on Thursday at 11:30am. 1/3 DRAZEN--Ruth Yorkin. KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Deborah; his daughters, Rebecca Katz (Matt Scharf) and Emily Katz (Laura Chapman), and grandchildren, Olivia, Benjamin, Leo and Eli. Also survived by his sister Miriam Cohen (Herb Cohen); sister-in-law Joan Rosenbaum (John Gorham); nephew Joshua Galper and niece Satya Welch and their families. Born and raised in the Bronx, beloved son of the late Charlotte (Breuer) and Sirol Katz, Dr. Katz was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, Swarthmore College, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. A Board certified pathologist/hematologist/blood banker, Dr. Katz had a distinguished career at the American Red Cross for more than 30 years, including as Executive Director of Blood Services at National Headquarters. An avid, top-seeded masters tennis player and a man of great intellect who cared deeply about his family and the world around him, his life was guided by high moral and ethical standards. He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. For further information, contact www.sagelbloomfield.com. 1/3 KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. EISENPRESSER--George, passed away on January 22, 2016, surrounded by his beloved wife, Therese, and son, Jackson. He was 98 years of age. George was born on April 23, 1917 in Brooklyn, New York, and attended both City College and Pratt Institute. George was an accomplished businessman, Chairman and CEO of National Die and Button Mould Company. He loved sports, including fishing, golfing, skiing and horse racing. And was a great comrade among his peers. He practiced hatha yoga, deep breathing and exercised throughout his life. He also enjoyed collecting art and adding to his collection-and loaned selected pieces to museums. He had a sense of humor and outstanding charm with elegance and wit. Everyone loved him-children, adults, friends and peers. His writings and his conversations were always enlightening to hear. He was a World War II veteran and fought in battles and campaigns, including Ardennes, Central Europe, Rhineland, Normandy, Northern France, and Belgium. Throughout his life he belonged to many clubs, including the Seawane Country Club and the Lone Star Boat Club. He was a religious man and a member of Central Synagogue. For over 70 years he designed and manufactured varieties of metal stampings-nailheads, studs, rhinestones and settings, metal and covered buttons, buckles, and other metal works. His customers included leaders in the fashion industry, automotive, aviation, and the United States Military. He loved people and could converse with anyone on any level-he would always light up a room. His time in World War II as a French interpreter and radar specialist in the anti-aircraft division, and his participation in the Battle of the Bulge and the invasion of Normandy left him with many great stories that he loved to share. These stories always interested everyone who met him. He is survived by his wife-Therese; sister-Hilda; four children-Jackson/Marina, Marvin/Victoria, Robert, Eileen; two stepchildren-Pamela/Jay, James/Ana; eight grandchildren-Lana/David, Ivy, Abigail, Cooper, Maria, Marella, Brian, Tod; and his loyal dog-Guy. George will be deeply missed. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on January 28th at 10am to celebrate his life and profound contribution. 1/3 EISENPRESSER--George, passed away on January 22, 2016, surrounded by his beloved wife, Therese, and son, Jackson. REICH--Dr. Robert (Bob), a psychiatrist who treated patients in his Upper East Side and Great Neck practices and a clinical assistant professor at Mt. Sinai Medical School, died on Monday at 79. Born in Montreal, he attended McGill University, edited The McGill Daily, and earned his M.D. at the University of Saskatchewan, where he met Mary, his wife of 54 years. As head of Psychiatry for the New York City Welfare Department under Mayor Koch, he waged a prescient fight against the impending homeless crisis. His patients ranged from celebrities to the indigent, and he was deeply committed to each one as an individual. A broad smile and a winning sense of humor told you instantly that you were in the presence of someone who would sympathetically take the full measure of your being. His stamina was superhuman; he worked long hours and still made himself available round the clock until the day he entered the hospital. His involvement was uncommonly broad, running from child to geriatric, from drugs and talk therapy, to being a pioneer in public psychiatry. Lover of hootenannies, Leadbelly, and opera; gourmet and wine connoisseur; tennis player and fan; magnanimous host and storyteller, Dr. Reich is survived by Mary, two children, Jim and Sharon, and three grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Riverside North Chapel in Great Neck, on Friday, January 29, at 11:30 am. 1/3 REICH--Dr. Robert (Bob), a psychiatrist who treated patients in his Upper East Side and Great Neck practices and a clinical assistant professor at Mt. Sinai Medical School, died on Monday at 79. Born in Montreal, he attended McGill University, edited The McGill Daily, and earned his M.D. at the University of Saskatchewan, where he met Mary, his wife of 54 years. As head of Psychiatry for the New York City Welfare Department under Mayor Koch, he waged a prescient fight against the impending homeless crisis. His patients ranged from celebrities to the indigent, and he was deeply committed to each one as an individual. A broad smile and a winning sense of humor told you instantly that you were in the presence of someone who would sympathetically take the full measure of your being. His stamina was superhuman; he worked long hours and still made himself available round the clock until the day he entered the hospital. His involvement was uncommonly broad, running from child to geriatric, from drugs and talk therapy, to being a pioneer in public psychiatry. Lover of hootenannies, Leadbelly, and opera; gourmet and wine connoisseur; tennis player and fan; magnanimous host and storyteller, Dr. Reich is survived by Mary, two children, Jim and Sharon, and three grandchildren. SISKIND--Beth, (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), on the morning of January 25, 2016 in her New York City home. Born Beth Diana Mohel August 10, 1940, she spent her first 18 years in New Bedford, MA, graduated from New Bedford High School and earned a bachelor's degree at Skidmore College (1962). A high- light of her time at Skidmore was an 11-week trip to Europe's Festivals of Art and Music which she financed through her successful investments in the stock market beginning at the age of 13. While raising her two boys in Scarsdale, Beth earned a Master's degree from the New School of Social Research. Beth was a dedicated mother, wife and grandmother. A lover of the arts and education, she relished being an angel for plays on Broadway and her most passionate charity work included efforts on behalf of Brandeis University, and Skidmore College. She will be greatly missed by husband Donald, sister Judith Hertz, sons Steven and Edward, their wives Moira and Lucinda and grandchildren Leila, Samuel and James. KOSLOW--Howard B.,91, of Toms River, NJ, formerly of East Norwich, NY, passed away, Monday, January 25, 2016, at his home. Funeral Services will be held at 10am, Thursday, January 28 at Temple Beth Am Shalom, 1235 NJ-70, Lakewood, NJ 08701. Burial will follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Route 109-Farmingdale Rd, Farmingdale, NY 11735 at 1pm. The family will be sitting shiva Thursday evening and Friday 10-4pm in NJ. Howard was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 21, 1924. He graduated from James Madison High School where he will be honored on their Wall of Distinction later this year. He was an accomplished artist/illustrator and a lifetime member of The Society of Illustrators (New York). His paintings are part of the Air Force Permanent Collection, the Smithsonian's Air & Space and National Postal Museums, the National Park Service and many private and corporate collections. Prominent works include numerous US postage stamps, paintings for NASA and The US Coast Guard. He was awarded many honors for his paintings. Howard is survived by his wife, Helen, of 66 years with whom he loved to travel; two daughters, Kathi Meyer (Perry) of San Diego, CA, and Amy-Jo Willig (Jeffrey) of Melville, NY; his sister, Helene Mandelbaum; four grandchildren, Elicia and Ben Meyer, David and Andrew Willig, and many nieces and nephews. 1/3 KOSLOW--Howard B.,91, of Toms River, NJ, formerly of East Norwich, NY, passed away, Monday, January 25, 2016, at his home. PARDEE--Margaret. The Juilliard School is deeply saddened by the passing of violinist and pedagogue Margaret Pardee. A longtime Juilliard faculty member from 1942 until 2008, she also was an alumnus of the school. She was passionate about her art and teaching, and she nurtured her students. Many of her former students have gone on to successful careers as soloists and members of leading orchestras all over the world. Her generous gift of numerous, extraordinary violins and violas to the Juilliard instrument collection will also contribute to the next generation of players. We extend our condolences to her family, friends, colleagues, and students. Joseph W. KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. He is survived by his wife of 43 years Deborah; his daughters, Rebecca Katz (Matt Scharf) and Emily Katz (Laura Chapman), and grandchildren, Olivia, Benjamin, Leo and Eli. Also survived by his sister Miriam Cohen (Herb Cohen); sister-in-law Joan Rosenbaum (John Gorham); nephew Joshua Galper and niece Satya Welch and their families. Born and raised in the Bronx, beloved son of the late Charlotte (Breuer) and Sirol Katz, Dr. Katz was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, Swarthmore College, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. A Board certified pathologist/hematologist/blood banker, Dr. Katz had a distinguished career at the American Red Cross for more than 30 years, including as Executive Director of Blood Services at National Headquarters. An avid, top-seeded masters tennis player and a man of great intellect who cared deeply about his family and the world around him, his life was guided by high moral and ethical standards. He will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. For further information, contact www.sagelbloomfield.com. 1/3 KATZ--Alfred J.,M.D., 78, died on January 24, 2016 at his home in Rockville, MD. HUDNER--Hope Freeman. Artist, Designer, Mother and Friend. Hope F. Hudner died at home in Little Compton, RI on January 14, 2016 following a thirteen month battle with glioblastoma multiforme, a form of brain cancer. Hope is survived by her husband of 40 years, Michael, and her daughter, Bay, who were deeply involved as caregivers and comforters during the past year, and were at her side at the time of her peaceful passing. Hope is also survived by her aunt, Judy Freeman N. Gross; brothers, Ambassador Charles "Chas" W. Freeman, Jr. (Margaret Carpenter) and Robert P. Freeman (Inge Reist); their five children and nine grandchildren (Hope's grand-nieces and -nephews); siblings-in-law, Mr. Kennedy Hudner (Jennifer), Ms. Cornelia Futterman (Michael), and Ms. Kristina Beitman (Harty), and their five children. Hope was born on January 11, 1951 in Nassau, The Bahamas, and lived there until age 10, then alternating time in Southern California with years in Providence and Bristol, RI. Hope was predeceased by her son, Michael Ripley ("Rip") Hudner, and her parents (father, Charles Wellman Freeman, and mother, Carla Park Freeman, who died when Hope was 20 months old). Hope was largely raised by her two sets of deceased grandparents, Hovey T. and Marjorie W. Freeman of Providence and Bristol, and George C. and Fentress K. Park of Wollaston, MA and Roaring Brook, MI. Hope graduated from The Lincoln School, Providence (1969), Smith College (1973), and also acquired an MFA from New York University. The family lived in New York City from 1974 through 1994, and then resided in Little Compton and Providence, RI. Hope was an accomplished artist and designer with a portfolio including work in graphic, interior, jewelry, and apparel design. These efforts led to her 2013 creation of Hope Hudner Designs, focused on elegant silk infinity scarves. Hope was deeply involved in Rhode Island public service, including, at various times, board and/or development responsibilities at Moses Brown School, Women & Infants Hospital, Rhode Islanders Sponsoring Education (RISE), RISD Museum, Perennial Planters, The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America (Rhode Island), and Providence Preservation Society. Hope's social involvements included membership in the Providence Art Club, Colony Club of New York City, Lyford Cay Club, Sakonnet Golf Club, and Sakonnet Point Club. Hope had great admiration for the natural world and actively cultivated a sense of wonder: she was a faithful student of plants and flowers (as evidenced by the thousands of bulbs planted across Rhode Island, Maine, and New York); she loved sailing with her family and friends (countless excursions on Narragansett Bay and longer trips to Maine, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and Ireland number among the most special); and her keen curiosity led her to explore the far corners of the world, from Spain and Taiwan at age 18 to Antarctica at 49, covering every other continent and many countries in between. Hope had enormous energy, deep intelligence, natural grace, and remarkable warmth. She believed that life presented endless opportunity to learn, remarking on the tenth anniversary of her son's death that, "Each time it rains in our lives, we are given an opportunity for further growth. I am grateful for the challenges in my life as chances to grow and blossom." Hope faced her illness with the same fortitude and poise. While she was indeed a lifelong learner, Hope was perhaps most notable as a teacher of these invaluable lessons to the rest of us. Hope felt a profound duty to embrace everyone she encountered with love and kindness, and she shared this love of people and life like water from a fire hose. All within range were enriched by her presence and generosity of spirit. Hope inspired people to think lovingly and boldly on behalf of the larger community, themselves, and their friends, prompting many to find more inside themselves to enhance their own lives and those of others. A college classmate of Bay's said it beautifully in a recent note to Hope: "You feature prominently as an inspiration for the life I want to live-to pursue my interests, to live fully and with panache, to spend time in nature, and, most of all, to be kind to people. I know I am just one of the many, many people you affect in this way!" A celebration of Hope's life will be held in Little Compton in early June on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in Hope's memory be made to: the Rip Hudner Memorial Fund at Moses Brown School, Providence; Dr. Patrick Wen's Research in Neuro-Oncology at Dana Faber Cancer Institute, Boston; or a charity of your choice. Above all, the family encourages you to remember Hope by engaging with the world through love and kindness. 1/3 HUDNER--Hope Freeman. Artist, Designer, Mother and Friend. Hope F. FREY--Dale F. The Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of Dale F. Frey, past Chairman of its Board of Directors, one of its greatest champions and dear friend. Through his vision, passion and relentless dedication to cancer research, he had a lasting impact on human life. Under Dale's leadership for over 16 years, the Foundation grew exponentially and funded top young scientists in cancer research whose discoveries have dramatically advanced progress against cancer. He led the Foundation with the same wisdom and entrepreneurial spirit he used as the first Chairman of General Electric Asset Management. In 2010, the Dale F. Frey Award for Breakthrough Scientists was established in his honor to support the most outstanding young cancer researchers in the nation. Our hearts go out to his wife, Betty Ann, and his children and grandchildren. Alan Leventhal, Chair of the Board, and Lorraine Egan, President & CEO. 1/3 FREY--Dale F. FREY--Dale F.,83, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, January 26, 2016, at home in Weston, CT following a courageous battle with cancer. Born on August 14, 1932 in Manheim, PA, he was the son of the late Franklin William and Mary Adele (Strickler) Frey. Dale was a graduate of Franklin & Marshall College, where he later served as a Trustee and Chairman and supported funding of the college. He received an MBA in Economics and Accounting from New York University. After college, he went on to serve in the U.S. Air Force. Following the U.S. Air Force, he began his 40 year career at General Electric, beginning in 1957, where he served in many positions, including Vice President and Treasurer from 1980 to 1994, as well as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of General Electric Investment Corporation beginning in 1984. In 1994, he stepped back from his position as Vice President and Treasurer and remained in his positions of General Electric Investment Corporation until he retired in 1997. After retirement, he dedicated his time to numerous boards, including Yankee Candle Co. Inc., Roadway Express, Aftermarket Technology Corp., Praxair, Inc., and Community Health Systems. He was a member of Aurora Capital's advisory board, as well as Chairman of the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation, which he believed fully in. Under his leadership, he raised in excess of $160 million and funded 850 Cancer Researchers. Dale's passions ran deep, which was seen through his love for his family, friends, his career, and his never-ending desire and dedication for helping others. Dale is survived by his wife of 62 years Betty Ann (Heistand) Frey; his younger brother, John Gilbert Frey, and his wife Verdella, of Manheim, PA; sons, Scott Frey of Easton, CT, Philip Frey, and his wife Elizabeth, of Fredericksburg, TX, and Kyle Frey of Fredericksburg, TX; daughter, Susan Frey of Westport, CT; and his grandchildren Megan and Patrick Frey of Fredericksburg, TX. Dale F. Frey's funeral service will be held at the Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church, 2 South Hazel Street, Manheim, PA 17545 on Tuesday, February 2, 2016, from 12:00pm-1:00pm. A celebration of his life will take place at Bent Creek Country Club, 620 Bent Creek Drive, Lititz, PA 17543, from 2:00pm-6:00pm. In lieu of flowers, in Dale's memory, please consider a donation to the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation to support the Dale F. Frey Award for Breakthrough Scientists, One Exchange Plaza, Suite 302, New York, New York 10006. 1/3 FREY--Dale F.,83, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, January 26, 2016, at home in Weston, CT following a courageous battle with cancer. BERENBAUM--Alan, 64, a computer scientist, educator and renaissance man, died of an aggressive variety of T-cell lymphoma on January 27 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. He is survived by his devoted partner of 43 years, Eileen M. Lach, and his loving sisters May Berenbaum and Diane Berenbaum. Mr. Berenbaum, who earned his advanced degree in computer science from Princeton, spent more than 25 years as a scientist at Bell Labs, and most recently was the senior architect designing chips for Microchip Technologies. Holder of several patents, he also taught at The Cooper Union. To his extended circle of friends, Alan is remembered as an intoxicating, incisive conversationalist, at ease with subjects from quantum physics to Formula One racing to the absurdities of today's politics. He wore his brilliance with grace and humor. A celebration of his life and spirit will be held at the Frank E. Adoring grandfather of Julie, Amy and Anne Achenbaum, Benjamin and Jake Kounitz, Alex and Torie Bratt. Dear companion of Shirley Lindenbaum. SLOAN--Howard, WWII bomber pilot, former Chairman of New York Blood Center, died at 91. From a base in East Anglia during World War II, 19 year old Howard Sloan flew 33 missions over Germany. His B-24 was named "The Stork Club." When praised for his bravery, he would invariably respond: "Was there a choice?" Cheers erupted from a crowd on the beach when, piloting his plane home to the states after the war, he dipped his wings over the Inwood Country Club. Mr. Sloan was born in New York City on March 20, 1924. He graduated from the Woodmere Academy and Pawling Preparatory School, and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University, Class of '45W. He and his late wife, Sonny, along with George and Barbara Bush, were the only two married couples on campus. Dreams of business school were dashed by financial necessity and he joined his father's insurance company, Harris, Sloan and Finn. Characteristically, he turned the experience into a colorful one, representing clients such as Restaurant Associates; Richard Burton, who dispatched him to Rome to deliver a diamond he'd bought at auction for Elizabeth Taylor, or Cartier to present a love bracelet to Valentino, who insisted Howard personally fasten it on his wrist. He became an art insurer, developing great interest and knowledge of art in the process, befriending numerous artists and inspiring a lifetime of collecting: Mayan and PreColumbian sculpture, works by artists as diverse as Giacometti and Bill King, Henry Moore and Lindner. He acquired an art gallery, Multiples, for his wife, Sonny, and Marian Goodman to run. In 1990, he was invited by his friend and mentor, Charles Wohlstetter, to become a partner in the latter's acquisitions of hundreds of independent telephone companies from Alaska to California. They formed Continental Telephone, later known as Contel, in 1962. The company then agreed to be acquired by GTE, a combination that created the nation's largest local telephone company. Sloan remained on the Board of GTE until it was restructured as Verizon. In 1968, an American syndicate acquired an 18th century chateau in Bordeaux with Wohlstetter and Sloan installed as new owners. Chateau Bouscaut was the second most beautiful vineyard in Bordeaux, Sloan proclaimed, second, he said, because he didn't want to boast. Among the many American guests who flocked to visit, his favorite was Mary Lindsay, whom he overheard saying to her husband, then mayor of NYC, "John, if I have to see one more vineyard, I'll kill myself." To Sloan's eternal regret, Bouscat was sold in 1980. Mayor Lindsay brought Sloan onto the board of the Vivian Beaumont Theatre in 1984. At that time, according to Andre Bishop, current artistic director, "Nobody would give you a nickel for the Beaumont." It is now one of the leading theatrical companies in New York, if not the world. Mr. Sloan served on the Board until his death on Thursday. In 1977, Sloan joined the Board of Trustees of the New York Blood Center, of which he was Chairman from 1993 to 2000, nominating his successor, Howard Milstein. In January 2013, a congressional extension prepared by Representative Carolyn Maloney in recognition of Mr. Sloan's 15 years of distinguished service and dedication to NYBC's mission, was entered into the congressional record. She cited his humanitarian status and commended his leadership and tireless advocacy. For several years, he presided as Chairman of Northside Center for Child Development, founded by Kenneth and Mamie Clarke, earning a colleague's recent comment, "There was a time this place wouldn't have existed without Howard Sloan." He and his wife are to be honored for their dedication to Northside at a gala in May 2017. Howard Sloan died of kidney failure in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital on January 21, 2016. Handsome as a film star, he will be remembered for his elegance and extraordinary wit. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Kathryn Roth of Weston, Massachusetts, Gillis Cone of Woodbury, Connecticut; a son, Douglas Sloan, of Palm Beach; a stepdaughter, Paulette Bartlett Robinson, of Los Angeles, and four grandchildren. Interment will be private and a memorial service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Wednesday, February 10th. 1/3 SLOAN--Howard, WWII bomber pilot, former Chairman of New York Blood Center, died at 91. MANBER--Malcolm Manuel, 89, passed away on January 23, 2016 in New York City. He was born on September 10, 1926 in Chelsea, MA to Gustave and Ida Manber and grew up in New York City. Beloved father of Susan and David Manber, grandfather of Max and Sarina Abraham and brother of Edna Dressner, Malcolm was married for 49 years to Vivienne Marianne Schulman and was a resident of New York City and Rhinebeck, NY. He served as an Army radio operator during World War II and later attended the Columbia Missouri School of Journalism. He enjoyed a renowned career as a science writer at the Bayonne Times, The Newark Evening News, Medical World News and Physicians Weekly. Among many notable articles, Mr. Manber published one of the earliest accounts of the world's first artificial heart transplant performed by Dr. Robert Jarvik. Mr. Manber and his wife took great pleasure in being founding members of the Beekman Arms Antique Market in Rhinebeck where their business, Victorian Cupboard, specialized in English pottery for more than 35 years. Special thanks to the hospice team at NYU Langone for making his last days with family and friends peaceful and serene. Donations in Mr. Manber's name may be made to the American Cancer Society. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3 MANBER--Malcolm Manuel, 89, passed away on January 23, 2016 in New York City. BERNSTEIN--Jeffrey M.,55, passed away at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on Wednesday, January 27, after a battle with lymphoma. Jeff was born in Englewood, New Jersey to Cynthia and the late Leopold Bernstein. He graduated from the Center for Open Education in 1978 and from American University in 1982. Jeff had a long career in the music industry as a producer, composer and writer, known for composing the theme song for the PBS show, "Postcards from Buster." Jeff also played the upright bass, the guitar and African drums. Jeff will be remembered for his humor, wit, passion, intellect, kindness and generosity. He made friends wherever he went. Jeff is survived by his loving wife, Shonda, his son, Noble Archer, three, residing together in New York City, his mother Cynthia, residing in Haworth, NJ, and his sister Debbie, residing with her husband, Paul, in Doylestown, PA. He will be missed by his nieces, Jennifer and Stephanie. A memorial service will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY at 2:00pm on Sunday, January 31. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jeffrey's memory to the Center for Advancement in Cancer Education, 130 Almshouse Road, Suite 107A, Richboro, PA 18954, www.beatcancer.org. 1/3 BERNSTEIN--Jeffrey M.,55, passed away at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on Wednesday, January 27, after a battle with lymphoma. GINSBERG--Robert K.,died peacefully on January 26, 2016 at age 91. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father and grandfather and an accomplished professional engineer. Born May 23, 1924 in New York City to Bill and Tania Ginsberg, he was educated at Lincoln School and Yale University and served as a Lieutenant (jg) in the United States Navy during World War II, seeing extensive combat in the Pacific. He was a lifelong New Yorker who practiced engineering as principal in the firm William Ginsberg Associates, and he was for more than five decades a national leader in the design and construction of newspaper production facilities. He is survived by his beloved wife of 37 years, Nellie Wilson. He was predeceased by his first wife, Helen (1926-71) and is survived by their three children, Nina (Charles Smith) of Richmond, CA, William (Ellen Kelly) of New Haven, CT and John (Kathleen) of New York City. He is also survived by his grandchildren (Alex Smith, Susan Smith Emberley, Emily Ginsberg Dellisant, Julian Ginsberg, Connor Ginsberg, and Nina Ginsberg) and many other dear family members. A superb whistler, he lived with song in his heart and on his lips throughout his nine decades of loves and laughs and friends and joys. Gentle, kind and loving, he will be forever missed. A memorial service will be announced. 1/3 GINSBERG--Robert K.,died peacefully on January 26, 2016 at age 91.
