LEVY--Bernard, passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 98. He was born in New York City on February 10, 1917 and attended New York University. Bernard was predeceased by his wife of 69 years, Laura Redfield Levy, who shared a love of life, travel, and dogs. He is survived by his sons Dean (Janice), Jonathan (Carol), and daughter Marcia Roesch (Geoffrey), and his seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren). Bernard was one of the most prominent dealers in early American furniture, first as a partner in the firm of Ginsburg & Levy, founded in 1901, and then from 1973 until his death with the firm Bernard & S. Dean Levy, Inc., of New York. Over the nearly 70 years as an active dealer, he was able to acquire and place a number of the most recognizable pieces in both private and public collections. He was a friend and advisor to many of the great early collectors, many of whose gifts now form the core of major museum collections. These include The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Bayou Bend Collection, The Winterthur Museum and Historic Deerfield among many other institutions. He was always eager to share his knowledge and enthusiasm with collectors, curators, other dealers and especially his family. His eye for the very finest in Americana will be missed. Bernard was an avid and accomplished tennis player winning many local and regional tournaments. Into his seventies he remained active in competitive tennis attaining a national ranking. Anyone who played with or against him can attest to a strong will and a wicked drop shot. Also, he always had a good joke to tell and enjoyed making others laugh. He will be greatly missed. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. 1/3 LEVY--Bernard, passed away peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 98. SCHWARTZ--Lewis G.,65, died Friday, January 29th at Stamford Hospital. Son of the late Edward Schwartz and Davida Schatz Edelson, Lew grew up in Meriden and West Hartford, Connecticut. He graduated from the Kingswood School (1968), Yale College (1972), and Cornell Law School. Lew began his legal career as an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan, later becoming a litigator at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. After returning to Connecticut, Lew became a partner specializing in employment law and litigation at Schatz & Schatz, Ribicoff & Kotkin, a firm started by his maternal grandfather that later merged with Shipman & Goodwin. In 2001, Lew joined Gartner, serving as Senior Vice President, General Counsel, Corporate Secretary, and Chief Compliance Officer, where he just celebrated his 15th year. Despite his myriad academic and professional accomplishments, Lew enjoyed no job more than his years as a coach and president of the North Stamford Little League. Lew's enthusiasm and love for life was boundless. He was an avid cyclist, wine enthusiast, and lifelong Yankee fan and 30-year season ticket holder. Lew's travels brought him to dozens of countries, and his network of friends and colleagues stretches around the world. Lew's most extraordinary role was as husband to Marjorie and father to sons Ethan and Alex, all of whom survive him and cherish his memory. The burial was private. For those wishing to honor him, please consider a donation to Stamford Hospital, sharecancersupport.org, or a charity of your choice. 1/3 SCHWARTZ--Lewis G.,65, died Friday, January 29th at Stamford Hospital. SMITH--Howard. NYU Lutheran's board and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of chair emeritus Howard Smith. As chairman of Lutheran Medical Center and Augustana Center from 1966 until 2004, Smith, who died Thursday at age 85, left an indelible legacy on southwest Brooklyn. With his friend New York City Mayor John Lindsay and the American Lutheran Church, Mr. Smith brokered the 1977 expansion and relocation of Lutheran Medical Center from 4th Avenue and 46th Street to its present location, a former warehouse at 55th Street and 2nd Avenue in Sunset Park. He facilitated the creation of the Sunset Park Family Health Center, now called NYU Lutheran Family Health Centers, the second largest federally qualified health center network in the nation. He created a lasting financial foundation for Lutheran through Health Plus, an innovative government-sponsored insurance program for low-income residents. Lutheran's sale of Health Plus to Amerigroup in 2011 created an endowment that continues to help modernize the health system. Mr. Smith, a lifelong Brooklyn resident, was chairman emeritus of the United Hospital Fund, former president of the Brooklyn Public Library Board of Trustees, and past vice president and director of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Smith received a bachelor's in chemical engineering from Princeton University and served in the U.S. Army. He served 40 years as president of Virginia Dare Extract Company, which was founded by his grandfather Bernard, and was a former director of Dime Savings Bank of New York before it merged with Washington Mutual in 2002. He is predeceased by his wife, Elsie, and survived by his three children, Howard Jr., Jean, and Lilla, and grandchildren. NYU Lutheran mourns as we celebrate Mr. Smith's life and legacy. A wake will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Tuesday, February 2, at 4-8pm. Services will be held at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, 7420 4th Ave., Brooklyn, on Wednesday, February 3, at 10 am. 1/3 SMITH--Howard. SMITH--Howard. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our chairman emeritus, a health care visionary and dedicated civic and business leader. Over six decades, Howard passionately championed innovations in hospital care and community health that are now understood broadly as essential to health reform. His ability to see opportunity and make important and timely decisions, was anchored by his deep belief in the imperative of community service. UHF benefited enormously from his skillful and steadfast leadership as our wise and caring chairman for 17 years and almost 40 years of active engagement on our board. He leaves an enduring legacy in health care and an indelible mark on his beloved Brooklyn and UHF. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children and remember with affection his wife, Rev. Elsie Smith, who shared and extended his commitment and dedication. J. Barclay Collins II Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President 1/3 SMITH--Howard. MURPHY--Hon. Francis T.,died peacefully on January 27, 2016 at the age of 88 surrounded by his family. He was married to his beloved Sheila Theresa for 55 wonderful years before her death on September 28, 2014. He is survived by their five children, Timothy F. Murphy and his wife, Pamela; Eileen and her husband, Jeffrey Forsyth; Kathleen and her husband, Lance Scott; Sheila and her husband, Michael Sproule; Annemarie and her husband, Kevin Casey; and his sister Irene McInerney. He was a loving grandfather to Casey, Kaitlyn, Timothy, Matthew, Sean, Patrick, Michael, Brendan, Megan and Liam. After being honorably discharged from the U.S. Navy after World War II, he graduated from Fordham University and New York Law School. A member of the New York judiciary for 40 years, he served 15 years as a trial judge and 25 years as a Justice of the Appellate Division First Department, with the last 20 years as the Court's Presiding Justice. When he left the Court, he joined the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye and Warren as Of Counsel. Throughout his career Judge Murphy was an ardent supporter of providing full legal services and justice to the underprivileged and incarcerated. A gracious man with a generous heart and strong religious beliefs, he took counsel only from his own conscience. The loves of Tim's life were his wife, Sheila, his family, his friends and his life in the law. Friends may call on Sunday, January, 31 from 2 to 4pm and 6 to 8pm at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 575 Fowler Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY on Monday, February 1 at 10am. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Judge Murphy's name to The Province of St. Mary (for the work of the Capuchin Franciscan Friars) at 210 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001 or donate online at: www.capuchin.org 1/3 MURPHY--Hon. LANEY--Christina B. Christina Bertrand Laney, age 83, of New York City died January 21, 2016. A classic "New Yorker," in every sense of the word, Christina was a native of the Upper West Side for over 50 years. She was an avid Riverside Park gardener, a frequent face at Fairway, and knew every sidewalk crack and crevasse of the Upper West Side. The daughter of Vera Federoff, of Ryazan, Russia, and Bertrand J. Laney, of New York City, Christina was born in Hankow, China, on December 28, 1932, her family fleeing China in 1940, shortly after the Japanese offensive. A true explorer, Christina traveled the world with her family, attending schools in China, Panama, El Salvador, and finally, at the University of Texas, and at New York University. It was in 1953, that Christina, in her own words, "found her Nirvana"-New York City. For over 30 years, she was involved in the entertainment industry, acting in small movie and television roles, then working behind the scenes in public relations, advertising, and film production. At United Artists, Christina was the Assistant to the Director of Special Projects for six years. She also worked for the Writer's Guild. Christina was a Vice President of Women of the Motion Picture Industry, and won their Dottie Reeves Humanitarian Award for Community Service. Christina's hobbies were manifold. Her diminutive size and powerhouse personality made her a natural spelunker. She was a member of the National Speleological Society for many years. A talented artist and poet in her own right, Christina supported Women in Motion Pictures, and the Curtain Club. She championed dozens of causes including: The Humane Society, The New York Historical Society, Sierra Club, The Wilderness Society, World Wildlife Fund, The Nature Conservancy, and the ASPCA. Christina was a lifelong volunteer for groups such as Channel 13, The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, and, for 50 years, the Riverside Park Conservancy, where she was honored for her volunteer contribution in her beloved garden on 78th Street and Riverside Drive. Before there was Google, there was Christina. A voracious reader and a fount of knowledge about a myriad of subjects, especially New York City, family and friends could always rely on Christina for an irrefutable answer. Into her 80s, Christina was a brilliant, plucky, feisty spitfire who continued to stimulate her mind by regular attendance at jazz concerts, museums, art galleries, and theater. She was a devoted sister, aunt, cousin, and friend-a tiny woman with a huge spirit, who will be deeply missed. Christina is survived by her older sister, Kera Toline Rogers of Charleston, SC; niece Catherine Anna Toline, husband Leo Lentsch; nephews, John Colin Toline, and son John, Mark Anderson Toline, wife Ann, and son North, and Paul Alexander Toline; and cousins, Barbara Laney Swenson of Hanover, New Hampshire, Ainslie Drummond of Florida, and Irene Morgan Kay of Australia. Christina's ashes will be interred in Moline, Illinois, with her parents and Russian grandmother, Barbara (Babi) Federoff. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Christina B.
